PROJECT AND SECTOR BACKGROUND Introduction 1.1 The province of Southeast Sulawesi (Sultra) covers a land area of 38,140 km2, while Central Sulawesi (Sulteng) covers a much larger land area, about 63,689 km2. Sultra has two Kabupatens which are part of the mainland Sulawesi Island. Two bigger islands, Muna and Buton and some smaller islands make up its two remaining Kabupatens and 30 percent of its area. Most of Sulteng is on the main Sulawesi Island but the province also has two medium island groups, the Banggai and Togian Islands, making up only about 6 percent of the land area. Sultra's population was estimated at 1.5 million in 1994 with an average density of about 39 persons/km2. The province has one of the highest population growth rates in the country, at about 3.7 percent per annum stemming from the fact that transmigration has been an important part of the province's recent past (the 1980s). Sulteng had an estimated population of 1.9 million in 1994 and growing at about 2.8 percent per annum. Population density is very low (29 persons/km2) except in the Palu valley where densities approach about 790 persons/km2. 1.2 Despite recent spurts of economic growth both provinces have low rural incomes and welfare levels. The population is generally sparse and unevenly distributed with the majority, 84 percent in Sultra and 85 percent in Sulteng, living in rural areas. The provinces of Southeast and Central Sulawesi are characterized by immense cultural diversity. In Sultra the major ethnic groups are Tolaki, the Tomekongga, and the Tomoronene on the peninsula, and the Wolio, Munese and Butonese on the Islands of Kabaena, Muna and Buton. In Sulteng there are reportedly 12 different ethnic groups and possibly twice the number of linguistic groups. The major ethnic groups include the Kaili, the Pamona, the Saluan, the Belantak, and the Banggai. Both provinces are now also home to migrants from other parts of Sulawesi such as the Buginese, the Makasarese, the Mandarese, the Gorontalos, the Manados, and the Bajaus as well as transmigrants from Java, Bali and Lombok. These transmigrants in 1990 made up a non-negligible part of the population of the two provinces (11 percent in Sultra and 6 percent in Sulteng). 1.3 Southeast and Central Sulawesi are two of Indonesia's provinces whose social indicators are not as good as national average (Table 1.1 below). In each province the estimated total population below the poverty line is above the national average. Both have low life expectancy levels even among the Eastern provinces, higher infant mortality rates, (surpassed only by NTB and East Timor in the East), high level of mal-nourishment and a relatively low literacy level. Health statistics indicate that the areas served per health center are on the high side especially for two relatively small provinces and hence availability of health facilities appears to be poor.

Source: Taken from Eastem Islands Rural Sector Strategy Review (Tables 1.8 and 1.10) Macroeconomic Background 1.4 Regional incomes, as measured by the Gross Regional Domestic Product excluding oil and gas (GRDP), have been growing at reasonably high rates for the two provinces since the early 1980s. The average annual GRDP growth rates were 7.2 percent for Central and 8.5 percent (one of the highest in the country) for Southeast Sulawesi between 1983-1992. These compare with a national GDP (without oil and gas) growth rate of about 7.4 percent for the same period. Though GRDP growth rate in Central Sulawesi (Sulteng) over 1983-92 was about equal to the average rate for the Eastern provinces, the higher than average population growth rate of the province led to a per capita GRDP growth rate below the regional average during the period. 1.5 The structure of the economy in Sulteng seemed to have changed rapidly between 1976 and 1983 when the share of agriculture fell from about 57 percent of GRDP to 42 percent. After 1983 however, the economic structure of the province changed very little with agriculture maintaining its dominant role in the province's economy. As of 1992 agriculture's share of output was still 44 percent and employed about 68 percent of the labor force. Southeast Sulawesi (Sultra) recorded one of the highest average GRDP growth rates in Indonesia but it remains well behind other provinces in the country in terms of the level of development. As of 1992, agriculture still dominated economic activity in Sultra with a share of GRDP of about 44 percent and employing about 76 percent of the labor force. In both provinces, industry accounted for only a limited share of provincial output and employment. Its contribution to output in 1992 was about 6 percent in Sulteng and 2.4 percent in Sultra. It also employed about 5.5 percent of the labor force in Sulteng and 4 percent in Sultra. 1.6 Exports. As of 1991, the principal exports from Sulteng in value terms were furniture and wooden construction materials (US$5.0 million), forest products (US$3.9 million) in the form of sawn timber (mostly ebony) and rattan, coconut products in the form of oil and copra (US$2.8 million), and sea products US$0.9 million. While the main exports from Sulteng have been from the agricultural sector, Sultra's principal exports
 3 have been from the mining sector. In 1991 mining exports (mostly nickel) were US$52.4 million, compared to US$2.7 million for fishery products and US$ 1.7 million in forestry products, mostly rattan. The Agricultural Sector 1.7 The agricultural sector is the largest sector in the economy of both Southeast and Central Sulawesi and provides the greatest source of employment. Growth in the provincial economies has been led to a large degree by the agriculture sectors whose growth rates averaged 7.7 percent per annum in Central and 8.0 percent per annum in Southeast Sulawesi over 1983-92. These growth rates were considerably higher than the 3.2 percent national average growth rate of the sector during the same period. The structures of the agricultural sectors of the two provinces are surprisingly very similar. Within the agriculture sector, the food crops and estate crops sectors are dominant in both provinces contributing approximately 75 percent of agricultural GRDP in 1992, with about 40 percent of agricultural value-added coming from farm foodcrops, 35 percent from the smallholder treecrop subsector. The contributions from the other subsectors were 10 percent from livestock, 12 percent from fisheries and about 3 percent from forestry. 1.8 The foodcrop subsector is still relatively large in both provinces and has been growing annually at an average of about 5.9 percent and 4.4 percent respectively in Central and Southeast Sulawesi. Paddy is the most widely planted food crop in both provinces, but the area planted in Central Sulawesi (149,700 ha) is significantly larger than the area planted in Southeast Sulawesi (74,100 ha). Major investments in irrigation facilities in both provinces combined with more intensive extension efforts for paddy have resulted in increases in production. However, average yields per hectare (3.3 tons) are about 1.4 tons less than the national average and there is potential to further increase output. Maize is the dominant staple food in some parts of Southeast Sulawesi (Muna and Buton) and the total area planted is reported to be just over 48,500 ha in this province while in Central Sulawesi only about 19,800 hectares are planted annually. Legume crops have been increasing in importance as compared to paddy and maize. Of the legume crops, soybeans are the most widely planted in both provinces (9,700 ha in Sultra and 14,600 ha in Sulteng). Other food sources, mainly sago, a food staple for some ethnic groups, are widely harvested from swampy areas in parts of both provinces. Cassava is also widely planted as a staple crop although it is less favored for consumption than rice. 1.9 In general, the smallholder treecrops subsectors in both provinces offer significant potential to increase farmer incomes and to contribute to conservation of land resources. While the subsector's contribution to agricultural GRDP did not change very much in Sulteng between 1983 (32.4 percent) and 1992 (34.5 percent), it rose rapidly from 15 percent to 35 percent in Sultra during the same period. In Sulteng, coconut is the most widely planted treecrop (164,390 ha) followed by cloves (51,500 ha), cocoa (29,900 ha), The review in the next two sections is derived for the most part from the recent sector study on Eastern Islands "Eastern Islands Rural Sector Strategy Review", Yellow Cover Report, November 1994
 4 and coffee (17,400 ha). In Sultra, cashew nuts are the most widely cultivated treecrop (123,900 ha), followed by cocoa (76,300 ha), coconuts (54,400 ha) and coffee (14,600 ha). 1.10 In Central Sulawesi, though the size of forestry output in total agricultural production is still relatively small (3.2 percent in 1992), forestry sector output increased faster than any other subsector at an average rate of over 13 percent per annum between 1983 and 1992. There appears however to be a problem of correctly monitoring forestry exploitation because of a lack of facilities and personnel of the forestry service. For this sector to continue to make a useful contribution to the province's economy, it is necessary to carefully study, monitor, and manage the forests and critical watersheds as part of forestry production and also in the agricultural and industrial development effort of the province. 1.11 Livestock and especially fisheries are growth areas in the two provinces that have good potential and for which market outlets exist outside the province and can make a useful contribution to poverty reduction. In Sulteng, the average annual growth rate of the fisheries sector over 1983-92 was 12 percent while for Sultra the rate was 11 percent. In both provinces, fisheries contribute significantly to exports and directly support over 6 percent of all households in the two provinces. 2 The respective livestock sector growth rates were 10 percent for Sulteng and 6 percent for Sultra. Constraints to Agricultural Development 1.12 Natural and Physical Constraints. Most of the Sulawesi peninsula is mountainous. The general terrain of Central Sulawesi and the northern part of Southeast Sulawesi is characterized by a narrow coastal plain often only a few kilometers in width and then steeply rugged mountain terrain still covered with forest. Central Sulawesi is a crescent-shaped province whose economic, political and social structure is heavily influenced by its geography. It is located on the equator, with high, steep elevations and dense forest cover. The mountainous region and poor infrastructure have led to scattered settlements and concentrations of population in the relatively more accessible but few coastal plains, such as the Palu Valley with some consequences on the environment in such areas. The soils in the northern part of the province are of volcanic origin, generally fertile and well-drained and are very suitable for the production of estate crops. In the rest of the province, the soils are of sedimentary and limestone origin, often less fertile than the volcanic soils but still suited to treecrop production. Southeast Sulawesi has a generally hilly and mountainous topography and only limited lowlands especially towards the north. South of the east-west Kendari-Kolaka line the land is flatter and more open. Soils are predominantly podsolic and Mediterranean, of limited fertility and, in certain parts, have low water-holding capacity. 2 Eastern Islands Rural Sector Strategy Review, Chap 5 Pg. 99.
 5 1.13 Land use data show that forests cover about 72 percent of the land area in Sulteng and 67 percent in Sultra and only about 10.3 percent in both provinces is used for agriculture and settlements. In many upland areas however shifting cultivation and extensive farming practices have expanded, resulting in soil erosion and loss of soil fertility. Both provinces have areas of high rainfall, but also some of the lowest rainfall areas in Indonesia. The general range of rainfall is between 800 to 3,000 mm except for the Palu area and southern Muna and Buton where annual precipitation of as low as 400 mm have been recorded. The generally mountainous topography of the provinces results in a diversity of localized micro-climates with unevenly distributed rainfall patterns during the year, placing a constant strain on rainfed production. 1.14 Levels of Technology. In general, levels of productivity in the agricultural sectors of the two provinces are below the national averages. There is therefore a significant potential to increase yields for all commodities both foodcrops and treecrops through introduction and dissemination of improved varieties and improved farming practices. Major problems to be overcome in increasing average yields include: (a) inadequate availability of improved seeds and seedlings for all commodities; (b) low demand for fertilizers for crops other than paddy stemming from ineffective extension programs introducing and explaining their use; (c) inadequate availability of and poor construction of irrigation facilities especially in the smaller irrigated areas; (d) inadequate extension programs to introduce effective pest management methods (including for vertebrate pests); and (e) inadequate post-harvest practices and storage facilities. For dryland cultivation, though population densities are low in the two provinces, the fragile nature of the soils demands greater attention to preserve shallow top soils and reduce the deterioration in soil fertility. This requires a change in the farming pattern of slash and burn and shifting cultivation. The need for the introduction of conservation farming techniques (hitherto not practiced) is therefore as important as in overcrowded Java and Bali. 1.15 Infrastructure. Sultra remains one of the remotest provinces of Indonesia though it has fairy good air and sea access to outside regions of South Sulawesi and Maluku. Sulteng on the other hand is relatively more accessible. Within both provinces transportation remains a key constraint. Paved roads connect most of the major towns but most of them are in a state of disrepair. There remains therefore considerable scope for further improving the state of the major road network. Regular ferry services and in some cases "speed" boats connect the mainland to the major islands and Kabupatens and also to the more remote islands and is the major means of transport in the region. Within each province however there are numerous access roads, village paths, and tracks that are impassable during the rainy season. In a lot of these areas, access by motor vehicles and carts is constrained and frequently farmers must carry all inputs and output. Improvement of these roads, as well as the main network of roads, would reduce transport costs and boost marketing of agricultural produce. 1.16 Policies and Incentives Affecting Agricultural Production. National level trade deregulation measures over the last five years have strongly impacted the treecrop
 6 subsector in both Southeast and Central Sulawesi. Following the deregulation packages of the early 1990s removing trade restrictions on coffee, copra and cocoa, the markets for these crops have become quite competitive, with farmers receiving remunerative prices and smallholder investments in these crops increasing sharply. 3 Under the general guise of raising local revenues, there are still a number of local and provincial taxes (or retribusi) imposed on the transport of certain commodities and animals and more especially on inter- regional trade. Though these are generally of a nuisance value, their effect on production and farmer incentives appears to be negligible. Despite the existence of a national quota system on inter-provincial livestock trade, the quota system is not enforced in Sultra and Sulteng and hence has no effect on livestock prices. 1.17 In some isolated cases, local district and even village authorities sometimes restrict competition by requiring produce to be sold through the local cooperative (KUD) or licensed traders. Following instructions from the Minister of Home Affairs (Keputusan Menteri Dalam Negeri No. 48/1984, amended by KEPMEN No. 29/1986) supported by instructions coming, from time to time, from the Governors to the Bupatis (e.g. Letter No. 512/1832/Ro. Ekon of 7 May 1994 from Governor of Central Sulawesi to all 4 Bupatis), there doesn't appear to be any more unusual local marketing restrictions or any new attempts by local authorities to limit competition by requiring produce to be sold through the local cooperative (KUD) or only licensed traders. Inputs (especially fertilizer) continue to be sold through the cooperatives and a limited number of licensed traders. This is however related to the national fertilizer subsidy program and the policy of PUSRI, the fertilizer company, to use only designated distributors. This system however does not appear to affect the availability or price of inputs in the major centers and farmers who have the means to acquire inputs should be able to get them either from Kabupaten or from some kecamatan centers. The production of stock seed from the Kabupaten Seed Centers (BBP) and extension seed from farmer seed growers provide less than half ofthe total seed requirements of farmers who now rely mainly on low yielding local and degenerated HYV varieties. Any new programs to improve agricultural productivity will therefore have to address the seed supply issue. 1.18 Capital Availability and Investments. The public sector continues to make the largest contribution to investments in the two provinces through the development budgets (APBN, APBD I and APBD II). Of the total development expenditures, an average of about 70 percent in Central Sulawesi and about 65 percent in Southeast Sulawesi came from the national development budget APBN, though the share of the two local development budgets had been increasing over the latter part of the Repelita V period. The total development budgets for both Southeast and Central Sulawesi more than doubled between the first and last years of Repelita V. They rose from about Rp. 99.6 billion for Southeast Sulawesi and Rp. 159.6 billion for Central Sulawesi in 1989/90 to about Rp 221 billion and Rp 450 billion respectively in 1993/94.  7 average estimated annual investment of around Rp 6 billion per province (2 percent and 1 percent of the development budgets of the two provinces) to be made under the proposed project. 1.19 In general, infrastructure and transportation has received the bulk of the development expenditures, especially at the local level. Agriculture's share in the national (APBN) and provincial (APBD I) development budgets has been slightly above 10 percent. At the Kabupaten level however the share of agriculture and irrigation in the development budget (APBD II) has averaged less than 4 percent for the two provinces. In 1993/94, the annual development budget for agriculture from APBN and APBD TK I & II had risen to Rp. 35 billion for Central Sulawesi and to Rp 48 billion for Southeast Sulawesi. On an annual basis, the proposed project investment would represent about 16 and 12.5 percent respectively of the annual agricultural development expenditures of the two provinces. Private sector investments in treecrop production over the last several years has been quite high though there is no data on the levels. Approved domestic and foreign investments have in general fluctuated significantly from year to year but over time have made up less than 0.9 percent of all domestic investment approvals in the country (11 percent of Eastern Indonesia) and less than 0.2 percent of all foreign investment approvals (3 percent of the approvals in Eastern Indonesia). 1.20 Agricultural Credit. In the two provinces, transactions through the banking system are very limited. The value added of the banking and financial services sector remains very small, making up less than 1 percent of GRDP in Southeast and less than 2 percent in Central Sulawesi. Most banks, at best, only have branches at the Kabupaten level and many of the promising rural financial service programs that have operated in the past and still operate in the country, including the relatively more successful Unit Desas (Kupedes) and P4K programs of the BRI (Bank Rakyat Indonesia) have operated only marginally in the two provinces if at all. I Access of farmers and other small-scale investors to financial resources therefore remains an important constraint for investment and they cannot rely on the formal banking and financial system to provide their credit needs. To avoid these problems of lack of access to credit facilities, sectoral projects often come with their own arrangements and mechanisms for input supply and some credit. As development projects and programs become regionalized, it would become necessary to explore alternative forms of rural finance mechanisms for the rural population, especially in the Eastern Islands. Experiences from Indonesia (Yogya Upland Project, Integrated Swamps project) and elsewhere (Albania Rural Poverty Alleviation Project, Benin Rural Savings and Loan Project) show that community-based savings and credit systems can provide useful alternatives. 1.21 Institutional Constraints. Government's current policy aims at gradually decentralizing responsibility for development to the local levels. Though there are adequate numbers of local government staff at both the provincial and kabupaten levels, there is a general lack of sufficiently trained and experienced staff to carry out the level of 4 Eastern Islands Rural Sector Strategy Review, Chap 3
 8 responsibilities that would accompany full and effective decentralization. Another important constraint for regional planning and implementing development, concerns the willingness and capacity of the local staff to take initiatives. Because the staff in the regions have mostly implemented centrally managed programs, tend to have a lower level of education, and limited experience, they are not accustomed to taking initiatives in planning and targeting development. A review of institutional capacity of key government and other agencies during project preparation identified the following constraints: * limited formal and on-the-job training opportunities as well as inadequate applied training; * inadequate provision of equipment and facilities and low levels of discretionary development funding at the kabupaten to support rural development activities effectively; * lack of reliable and relevant data on the regional (sub-district, district and/or provincial) economy for the purposes of proper development planning.

BANK INVOLVEMENT AND LESSONS LEARNED Experience with Area Development Operations. 2.1 Bank Wide Experience. 5 The Bank has supported a large number of area development projects, 45 percent of them in Africa. These projects, however, fell into disfavor in the mid-1980s following the evaluated poor performance of the earlier projects. In several countries, a series of projects had been launched in quick succession, leaving little time for learning and applying lessons from experience. Most evaluations, by the Bank as well as other donors, associated poor performance of these projects with project complexity and lack of flexibility, inadequate attention to village level institution building and beneficiary participation, poor policy and incentive framework, and lack of appropriate production technology, institutional capacity and government commitment. Notwithstanding the poor track record, some area development projects have been quite successful. OED studies have concluded that with good local management and appropriate policy framework, this type of project can be very effective. 2.2 Indonesian Experience. Area development type projects in Indonesia have been implemented with varying degrees of success and impact on poverty alleviation. Lack of sustainable technological packages for land and crop development, shortages of family labor, inadequate agricultural support services and poor inter-agency coordination were major constraints to realization of the development objectives of the swamp development projects, the transmigration projects, and the two upland area development projects (Yogyakarta Rural Development and the Upland Agriculture and Conservation projects) financed by the Bank. The Project Performance Audit Reports (PPAR) for three of the five transmigration projects concluded that while the resettlement objectives of these projects were satisfactorily achieved, the planned agricultural development necessary to generate income and employment for the transmigrants was deficient. 6 The first Bank- financed non-transmigration related area development project in Indonesia, the Yogyakarta Rural Development project, was also judged unsatisfactory by the PPAR on grounds of over-ambitious project objectives, faulty project design, and non-replicable and non-sustainable land development technology. 7 2.3 To some extent these problems were addressed in the design and/or during implementation of the second generation projects such as the Nusa Tenggara Agricultural Support Project (NTASP; 1986), and the Yogyakarta Upland Area Development Project (YUADP; 1991), resulting in their better implementation and development impact.  10 projects have made important contributions to the development of local level institutions, processes for decentralized planning, implementation of development activities, and experimented with approaches for beneficiary participation and use of project area CDOs. The NTASP and the UACP have been generating location specific upland and arid/semi- arid farming technologies, and fostering the much needed operational linkages between research and extension in the project areas. 2.4 Lessons Learnt. The main lessons learnt from the implementation of the two area development projects in Indonesia, NTASDP and YUADP, and as reflected in their Implementation Completion Reports are consistent with those from some 300 such Bank wide projects. These show that to succeed, area development projects need: (a) clear and unequivocal long-term political commitment to and policy support for rural development and poverty alleviation objectives; (b) beneficiary participation in the identification, planning and implementation process in order to ensure their 'ownership' of the project; (c) realistic, simple and flexible project design based on objective diagnosis of development constraints and their possible solutions; (d) proven technology and support services for production growth, or effective measures for technology development and their adoption during project implementation; (e) demonstrated institutional capability at the local level for project implementation, or effective measures to strengthen existing institutions early in project implementation; (f) routine monitoring and periodic evaluation of project implementation and impact, as a basis for 'mid-course' corrections; and (g) to avoid the involvement of excessive number of agencies and satisfactory inter-agency coordination where integrated/simultaneous implementation of several different components are necessary for synergistic benefits. In addition, experience has shown that sustainability of development impact is enhanced if the project structure is integrated with standard local development administration, rather that a super-imposed specialized project administration. The proposed project will incorporate these lessons through simple and flexible design and by limiting activities principally to the agricultural sector. Mid-Term evaluation will also be an important feature of the project for project redesign in response to any changed circumstances. Government's Development Strategy. 2.5 Government's overall strategy for growth, poverty alleviation and regional development has had the following key elements: (a) fostering rapid growth of the major income and employment generating sectors of the economy: agriculture, industry, and services; (b) promoting rural urban linkages and migration out of overpopulated and resource constrained areas; and (c) investing in physical infrastructure and human resource development. For reasons of social equity and regional balance however, the Government of Indonesia (GOI) has placed particular emphasis on the development of the eastern islands during the Second Development Period, PJP II, and during REPELITA VI. GOI strategy for the East emphasizes human resource and physical infrastructure development, productivity gains in agriculture, agribusiness and small scale village processing, and
 11 integrated area development activities. The specific strategy for the project areas is similar to the rest of the East and puts emphasis on: * agricultural development, with particular emphasis on productivity increases, agri-business, development of potential irrigation sites, and improvements in agricultural services; * infrastructure development, particularly road transportation, facilities for inter- island transport, and communications infrastructure; * human resource development; * industrial development, particularly in the form of agro-processing and mining; and * deconcentration of governmental activities and some decentralization of decision making, giving increasing powers to the local level institutions on development administration; 2.6 The last element of the strategy dealing with decentralization is particularly important for Government's regional development program. It is expected to be linked with increased general purpose transfers that would permit provinces and districts to finance their development programs without restrictions from the center and permit them to provide counterpart funds directly for externally funded projects. Two elements of government's strategy that is important for poverty alleviation and hence relevant to the Eastern regional development effort is the recently instituted INPRES Desa Tertinggal (IDT), designed specifically to target villages that are at or below the poverty level and the integrated area development program (PPWT) sponsored by the Ministry of Home Affairs through its regional development directorate, BANGDA. 2.7 Regional Development Objectives. Regional development objectives in both Southeast and Central Sulawesi as contained in their respective regional development plans, reflect those at the national level and emphasize: (i) achieving sustainable economic growth; (ii) reducing the incidence of poverty through broad-based income generation; and (iii) promoting a more equitable pattern of growth to reduce inter-regional disparities. In both of these provinces, the key regional development priorities are: rural and community development; improvements in agricultural productivity; development of agro-industry and agri-business; roads and infrastructure development to support regional development; natural resource conservation; and human resource development.

Bank's Strategy 2.8 Agricultural Sector Strategy. The main objectives of the Bank's evolving strategy in the agricultural sector are to ensure agricultural growth with distributional equity, and to assist in rural poverty alleviation through income generation.8 To achieve this, the Bank envisages an increased emphasis on regional operations, designed: (a) to adapt development programs to the specific constraints and conditions of each area or region involved; (b) to improve and focus provision of agricultural services (extension, research, input distribution, etc.) in needed areas; (c) to elicit an increased local participation in planning and implementation of operations; and (d) to strengthen local institutions to be effective in assisting farmers in increasing their incomes and in evaluating development effectiveness. 2.9 While agriculture is unlikely to be a major source of growth in the Indonesian economy as a whole in the near future, growth in the sector is still a key element of development and poverty alleviation strategy in provinces such as those in the proposed project regions where a high percentage of the population depends on agriculture and where 40 to 50 percent of regional GDP still comes from agriculture. Thus the Bank's focus would be to develop agricultural operations which raise productivity, rural incomes and reduce poverty in the regions as a complement to sector-wide investments, national policy reforms, and institutional change. In the remote, resource-poor regions where poverty is more entrenched, such as the Eastern Islands, the Bank's strategy would be to implement carefully designed and special interventions addressing issues of sustainable improvements in farm incomes and productivity, and off-farm incomes where possible. Project design also seeks to ensure appropriate support to non-agricultural activities that directly affect agricultural production. The project would thus include activities, such as village infrastructure that would support the rural development process and poverty alleviation. 2.10 Country Assistance Strategy and Rationale for Bank Involvement. The above strategy and proposals included in the proposed project are consistent with the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy for Indonesia, discussed in the meeting of Executive Directors held on March 21, 1995, supports the Government in the following key areas: (a) maintaining growth with macro-economic stability; (b) enhancing competitiveness; (c) reducing poverty; (d) enhancing human resource development; and (e) managing resources sustainably. The proposed project reflects the more decentralized region- specific approach that is now emerging and is consistent with the Bank assistance strategy's basic approaches for poverty alleviation and decentralization of development activities. THE PROJECT Project Origin 3.1 Historically, Bank support for the agricultural sector has been through projects financed through central sectoral agencies - sectoral operations with components in the provinces. A number of these operations have and continue to have a positive impact on poverty reduction and the growth of the regions, especially when they have financed irrigation and other infrastructure or sought to transfer know-how and technology from one area to the other, and where central coordination is required. The recent Eastern Islands Rural Sector Strategy Study however strongly argued for area development operations that would not only complement the sector projects but would seek to improve the impact of development operations by: (a) reflecting specific local conditions (e.g., farming systems, soil conditions, etc.) in project design; (b) taking into account the immediate priorities of the regions; and (c) permitting a high level of beneficiary participation in planning and implementation. 9 The proposed project responds to this recommendation from the study. Project Objectives 3.2 The overall objectives of the project are to assist Government in reducing the incidence of poverty in the provinces of Central and Southeast Sulawesi through the increase of rural incomes, the promotion of equitable regional development, the promotion of environmentally sustainable farming practices, and the strengthening of local level institutions. Its specific project objectives are: * to increase farmer productivity and incomes; * to promote environmentally sustainable farming practices; and * to improve the capacity of local institutions to identify, prepare, appraise and manage agricultural development programs. Project Target Areas 3.3 A number of project target areas and activities have been selected by local government authorities based on inputs from the rural population in the bottom-up planning process that went into the preparation of Repelita VI. Other priority areas and activities were also added following field discussions during preparation. The main criteria that guided the selection of project locations were: a) to reach a large number of households below or near the poverty line, 9 Eastem Islands Report op. cit. Chap. 2
 15 b) to provide assistance to areas with significant potential for agricultural development that have hitherto been neglected or only marginally been touched by other operations; c) to cover areas identified as requiring special attention in the provincial and district Repelita VI; and d) areas where there is a minimum level of government support services as well as infrastructure to connect them to regional centers. 3.4 The proposed project will be implemented in all eight Kabupatens of the provinces of Southeast and Central Sulawesi, with particular focus on the lesser developed Kecamatans. The target areas selected in Central Sulawesi are located in 27 Kecamatans with a total land area of some 22,500 sq. km (35 percent of the land area) and covering 585 villages of which 286 or 49 percent have been classified as poor. The target area has an estimated population of 625,000 people (129,000 households) or 33 percent of the province's population . The target areas in Southeast Sulawesi are in 25 Kecamatans, with a land area of 22,000 sq. km (58 percent of the area) and would involve some 289 villages of which about 160 or 55 percent are classified poor. The estimated population of the target area is 426,000 (84,100 households) or 31 percent of the total population. The target areas in general, are outside of the traditional areas that receive donor assistance around Kendari and Palu. Detailed Project Features 3.5 The project has three broad components covering: (a) agriculture-based area development; (b) capacity strengthening and project management; and (c) farming systems and fisheries research support and technology transfer. Component A: Agriculture-Based Area Development (US$ 26.4 million; 80 percent of total base cost) 3.6 This component aims to improve agricultural productivity, incomes and levels of welfare of rural households in the 54 Kecamatans by implementing a program of agricultural development activities. A secondary objective would be to improve the pattern of agricultural land use and reduce soil erosion and loss of soil fertility from traditional farming practices. Several activities (described below) have been identified to constitute a core menu from which the specific activities for each area have been proposed, taking into account the area's resource base. The menu identified includes: improved cropping in village irrigation schemes, dryland farming systems development, cattle distribution, household technology packages, and vaccination of chickens against Newcastle disease. In addition, the project would also support the improvement of critical road sections, bridges and culverts to improve communications between farms and markets, and includes
 16 an as yet unidentified component of other development activities to be proposed by local communities during implementation. 3.7 The agricultural development activity in each area would consist of direct input and equipment support for demonstration plots in farmers' fields, and basic extension and financial support for replication in the farming activities included in the menu. A village level revolving credit system (following a successful model developed in an Albania operation and also a similar one in the ongoing Yogyakarta Upland Project) will be set up to provide the financial support for the replication program. Annual work programs and budgets for each area would be based on a community-based planning system. Existing women farmer groups (wanita tani) would have the same access to the village revolving credit system, as well as any other project support available to other farmer groups. 3.8 Activities would be grouped into four sub-components: (a) Crop Development program (including foodcrop and tree crop activities); (b) livestock production and veterinary care; (c) Farm access roads; and (d) Community-based initiatives. 3.9 Crop Development Program. The crop development program would cover foodcrop, horticulture and treecrop production systems. The main activities to be financed would include: (a) Irrigation Farming System. The project would finance improvement of agricultural practices on village irrigation schemes where water control structures are being constructed under the Governments crash Village Irrigation Program (PID). The project would support the establishment of demonstration plots of 3 ha each in adjacent 0.5 ha farm plots involving six farmers in each of the 203 irrigation schemes being rehabilitated in the project area, and support improved seed multiplication for rice, soybean, mungbean and maize. This would average about 2 ha seed multiplication units for each 3 schemes for a total of 20 seed units in Southeast and about 48 units for Central. In addition the project includes extension support for improved irrigation cultivation (Annex 1 Section A). Farmers would be able to obtain credit under the village revolving credit scheme for replication (Annex 1 Section I). (b) Dryland Farming. The project would finance the introduction and extension support for the promotion of conservation (dryland) farming technology for upland farmers using alley-cropping, bench terracing, contour ridge terracing (covering treecrops, fruit trees and foodcrops), soil conservation techniques, and rehabilitation of smallholder treecrop plantations. Some of these dryland technology packages have recently been introduced in some of the Eastern Island provinces such as NTB and NTT though they are more widely practiced in the uplands of the more heavily populated Java and Bali. The technology packages are also practiced in small pockets of Sulawesi with support from community development organizations (CDO). To introduce the packages, the

(Annex 1 Section C) (c) Treecrop Rehabilitation. The project would also provide for demonstration of rehabilitation of existing overgrown cashew and cacao farms. In each case there will be 3 ha demonstration plots in the cacao or cashew villages. There will be a total of 72 cacao demonstration plots (covering 216 ha) in Central Sulawesi and 90 plots (270 ha) each of cacao and cashew demonstration in Southeast Sulawesi. The project would also provide support for the establishment of one small private treecrops nursery for every 3 villages to provide improved seedling (Annex 1 Section E). The project also includes arrangements for the provision of group credit to give farmers access to liquidity they can use to finance inputs they would need to replicate the new technology. (d) Household Plots. The component includes promotion of packages through extension support and demonstration activities to upgrade existing household technologies (such as house gardens, improved hearths, drying floors etc.), which are traditionally the responsibilities of women (Annex 1 Section F). 3.10 In order to ensure that farmers who want to adopt and replicate project activities and project introduced technology have the means to do so, the project would finance a village-level revolving credit fund that would make liquidity available to farmer groups for input purchase, crop marketing and agricultural processing. Government has agreed at negotiations to pass on the credit as a grant to villages. Despite the fact that funds will be a grant to participating villages, farmer groups and individual farmers would have to repay the credit with a minimum interest rate of 15 percent per year in the initial years and a higher rate in the latter years so that the fund continues to serve village members in the future. Individual communities will however be able to charge higher rates if they wish. Each participating village would receive an initial revolving credit that would not exceed Rp 10 million for on-lending to villagers, farmers, and farmer groups in the village. For replication credits the technical services (Dinas/PPLs) would need to assure themselves that the groups in question are adopting the recommended technology. Repayment would be after the planting season and would be made to a special account to be opened by each village at the nearest institution providing deposit services, expected to be either a commercial bank or post office (pos giro). While the basic objective of the program would be to ensure that farmers are able to replicate the agricultural programs, it was agreed that up to 40 percent of the village funds can be on-lent for agricultural processing and marketing to be undertaken by the villagers or groups within the village. The Government of Indonesia, since the introduction of the BIMAS (mass guidance) in the early sixties, has considered seed production to be one of the five major aspects in foodcrops (especially rice) production improvement. The provision of foundation seed has therefore traditionally been the responsibility of research. First stage multiplication has normally been done by provincial and kabupaten seed farms for distribution to farmers. The seed multiplication program has been supported by various Government policies on seed certification. Private sector involvement in this area has been virtually non-existent since the B1MAS subsidized seed policy kept them out in a major way from seed production. However, the implementation of the BIMAS seed policies has faced major constraints at provincial and kabupaten level, so that the availability of extension seeds at the farming level is not sufficient, in particular in the more remote areas in Indonesia, away from Java and Bali and the operation of existing seed multiplication centers has been poor. The project would provide some funds to rehabilitate and to support the operation of one seed center per Kabupaten to produce stock seed, for multiplication by seed farmers, provided a management plan is prepared and implemented for each center to be supported. The Plan would cover: - operational program to produce the required stock seed based on available area; o cost of seed production and expected production; o proposals on how the produced stock seed will be marketed and expected sales revenue; o proposals on origin of foundation seed, 3.20 The stock seed to be produced at these centers would be sold to seed farmers who would multiply them for sale to other farmers or for their own use. Financing of Proposed Development Activities and Cost Recovery 4.3 The project would finance several crop development demonstration activities covering irrigation, dryland farming, treecrop rehabilitation, and homegarden improvement. All labor for demonstration activities and crop replication in the different types of activities as well as labor for village infrastructure works will be supplied by farmers. Annual inputs for irrigated cropping demonstrations, including farm tools, improved seeds and fertilizers, would be supplied for two cropping cycles as grants to the farmers participating in the demonstration programs. This subsidy is justified as these early adopters would provide a demonstration effect for follower adopters.'3 There would be one 2 ha demonstration per irrigation scheme with total area of demonstrations covering about six percent of the targeted area of selected village irrigation schemes. Support will also be provided for farmer seed growers to multiply improved seeds for sale to other farmers, so as to initiate the introduction of improved varieties. Funds would be provided through a village revolving credit scheme (para 4.6) for farmers who may want to replicate the demonstration programs to purchase inputs. This one time grant to villages would become a sustainable source of seasonal funding for farmers who would repay to their communities at real and positive interest rates. 4.4 For dryland cropping the project would supply farm tools, fertilizers and other required inputs for establishing demonstration farms and assistance for establishing tree crop nurseries and for producing improved food crop seeds. Again the subsidy involved in 13 In economic language: these early adopters confer an extemality for follower adopters.
 27 demonstration is justified due to the externality they generate for follower farmers. Those who will want to replicate the dryland farming program may do so through the village revolving credit scheme (para 4.6). There will be a one 3 ha demonstration farm for each 2 villages. Support for the demonstration and seed/seedling production programs will be for two years. For houseplot cropping, arrangements would be similar as for dryland cropping. There will be 2 demonstrations per village, each equivalent to about 0.2 ha. Farmers' contribution will be in the form of labor for the demonstration activities. 4.5 For cattle raising the project would supply breeding stock to selected farmers who: have developed or are already using sustainable farm practices; have not owned livestock before; followed all the training; agree to develop the needed fencing and stables; and have enough fodder crops planted to feed two animals year around. Priority will also be given to farmers with a farm income below the average for the kecamatan. Participating farmers would contract to return 2 heifers (1.5 years old) per cow received (farmers who received a bull and a cow pay 3 heifers). Beneficiaries of the cattle distribution program would return the second and third born calves for redistribution among other interested farmers or for sale (usually the male calves) to cover part of the operating cost of the livestock support services. An assurance to this effect was obtained during negotiations. Management of the distribution and the cattle revolving credit programs would be by the beneficiary communities (para 3.12 and Annex 1 Section G). 4.6 Inputs for Replication and Village-Level Revolving Credit. Though various productivity improvement programs, financed by the Government, provide some means of purchasing some agricultural inputs, direct farmer access to credit for input purchase is often difficult. The commercial banking system has not shown much interest in managing direct farmer credits and hence the project cannot rely on them to finance credits for inputs. Project funds will be used to pay for inputs and even though the funds will be passed on as a grant to the village farmers will be required to pay back the value of the inputs, including interest, to the village to set up a village revolving credit. The credit will not finance labor for replication since this is expected to be provided by the farmers. Promising experiments are currently underway in Indonesia under the Yogyakarta Upland Area Development Project (Loan 3305-IND) and the Integrated Swamps Development Project (Loan 3755-IND) with farmer-managed revolving credit schemes. The proposed project would therefore finance a similar scheme that would make funds available to farmer groups for input purchase. 4.7 It is expected that community development facilitators (CDFs) and extension agents (PPLs) would help farmers to organize themselves into farmer groups and help them prepare proposals for replication of project-introduced technology that would be reviewed by the appropriate Dinas for inclusion in the annual program and financing plan. Terms of reference of the CDFs is in Annex I Appendix A. Funds will be a one-time grant to participating villages, but farmer groups and individual farmers would have to repay the credit with a minimum interest rate of 15 percent per year in the initial years and a higher rate in the latter years. Individual communities will however be able to charge higher rates if they wish. Management of the credit will be by a village credit committee that will
 28 decide on credit terms, and ensure repayments. Details on operating conditions for the credit were discussed at negotiations and are in Annex 1. Section I. 4.8 Each participating village would receive a revolving credit that would not exceed Rp 10 million/year for distribution to farmer groups in the village. Repayments may be given in priority to new farmers willing to adopt the package in the same village. Peer pressure within the village setting is expected to lead to high rates of reimbursement as is the case under the Hamlet Credit program of the Yogya Upland Agriculture Development Project. In addition it is proposed that as part of the process of ensuring full repayment, villages with farmer groups having overdue loans may not be provided further grants. Over time, other farmers may either become members of already existing groups, or form new groups. As experience with grassroots credit schemes under this and other projects evolves, the training of facilitators would be updated and new formats would be introduced. Assurance was obtained at negotiations that operation of the village grant and revolving credit program would be under agreed conditions. Details on the operating conditions under the village revolving credit scheme including regulations, operational guidelines, and credit conditions for the revolving credit system (Annex 1 Section l) were discussed and agreed during negotiations. Procurement 4.9 General. Goods and works would be procured in accordance with the provisions of the "Guidelines for the Procurement under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits", published by the Bank in January 1995 and revised in January 1996. Procurement under the project would be undertaken by the respective implementing units under the guidance and control of provincial and/or national parent agencies. Bulking and grouping of contracts across agencies or provinces would not be practical and has therefore not been adopted. GOI would finance purchases of vehicles and fertilizer (urea, TSP. and KCL) from its own resources because under GOI procurement rules these items are not open for international competitive bidding. Farmers may however use funds from the grant component for financing replication inputs to purchase fertilizers. This component will be financed at 70 percent to take account of the fact that the share of fertilizer in the inputs to be purchased is about 30 percent to be financed by Government. Procurement of vehicles would be in accordance with a schedule and timetable agreed with the Bank. An assurance to this effect was obtained from GOI during negotiations 4.10 Civil Works. Contracts for the rehabilitation of agricultural extension centers, seed farms, and animal health posts (US$0.7 million) are expected to be relatively small and would be widely dispersed over the two provinces. The major part (US$0.6 million) would therefore be procured by national competitive bidding (NCB) procedures acceptable to the Bank. A small part of such contracts (US$0.1 million ) would involve very minor works dispersed over time and space and may, with the Bank's prior agreement, be procured on force account. Contracts for roads, bridges and culverts (US$10.8 million) would normally be small, costing less than $50,000 each and would be procured using simplified procurement procedures similar to national shopping. The invitation would include a detailed description of the works, including basic specifications, the required completion date, a basic form of agreement acceptable to the Bank, and relevant drawings, where applicable. The award would be made to the contractor who offers the lowest price quotation for the required work, and who has the experience and resources to complete the contract successfully. 4.11 Equipment and Agricultural Inputs. ORGANIZATION, IMPLEMENTATION AND MONITORING Organizational Structure 5.1 The proposed project would be implemented in a decentralized, multi-sectoral manner with primary responsibility for project implementation at the Kabupaten and lower levels, for purposes of ensuring ownership of the project of the local Governments and the rural population. Organizational arrangements are shown in Chart 1. Project managers would mostly be at the Kabupaten level (TK II). This decentralized project implementation approach will ensure that the two principal project components; the agriculture-based area development, and capacity strengthening, will be directly implemented by the local governments. 5.2 At the national level, a Central Guidance committee (CGC) chaired by BAPPENAS (Deputy V Regional Development) and including, among others, representatives from the Ministries of Home Affairs (DG Regional Development, and Director Area Development), Finance and Agriculture (DGFCH, DGLS, DGE, DG Fisheries, and DG AARD) will be responsible for providing policy guidance and coordination, for reviewing project progress, and resolving issues on overall Loan administration. To provide support for the CGC and to coordinate project activities, a small project secretariat will be set up at the Directorate of Area Development in BANGDA. This unit is expected to maintain close liaison with the Directorate Generals of Food Crops, Estate Crops, Livestock and Fisheries, all of the Ministry of Agriculture, to ensure that appropriate technical support from the sector agencies can be given to the provinces and Kabupatens when necessary. The project secretariat will ensure that the above four DGs participate at least twice a year in project supervision. The main activities of the unit will be: (a) to coordinate project planning and budgeting at the national and provincial levels; (b) to review annual work plans and budgets and process the Decision Letter for Budget Assistance (SPABP) for the provinces; (c) to monitor and evaluate project implementation and impact; (d) to prepare periodic project progress reports (annual/semi-annual); (e) to implement national level activities such as project orientation workshops, coordination, recruitment of consultants, etc.; and (f) to liaise with the Bank, administer loan disbursements and consolidate project accounts from the provinces.

Implementation Arrangements 5.6 The approach for implementing the Agriculture Development Component has been formulated to maximize the participation of the targeted beneficiaries in selecting, planning and implementing the project interventions. Project activities would be planned through the existing bottom-up planning system with field extension workers (FEW) and community development facilitators (CDF) assisting rural communities in planning of project activities. The facilitators, to be recruited on contract by the project, may be recruited locally, from universities, or from among CDOs. They, together with the FEW and other community development staff, would help farmers and farmer groups: (a) to identify their main constraints and priority needs; (b) to review the menu of activities and select the most appropriate option provided by the project that is needed in their village based on the natural conditions and comparative advantage of the area; (c) to prepare a request and submit this request through the bottom-up planning process for financing; (d) to prepare and implement the agreed on activity including management of any village level revolving credit that the group may ask for; and (e) to monitor, evaluate and make mid-course corrections in project implementation as necessary 5.7 The village level proposals would be reviewed and consolidated at the Kecamatan level and retained proposals will be sent to the Kabupaten level. The Kabupaten project staff will review all project proposals and prepare a draft annual operational plan and budget for onward transmission to the provincial level steering committee for review and adoption. 5.8 Apart from the options provided through the identified menu of activities, rural communities and local CDOs would also be encouraged to identify other priorities, not included in the core menu, for development in their communities and prepare proposals for assistance under a community development fund included as part of the project. Under this program, the CDFs and FEWs will assist farmers, farmer groups and/or village communities to identify activities and make proposals for funding. The village level proposals, formulated by farmer groups and/or villages with assistance from the community development facilitators, will be consolidated at the Kecamatan level and reviewed for funding as described in para 3.15 and Annex 1 Section H.
 36 5.9 Given the limited capacity existing at the local levels to manage and teach community-based development, it is proposed that the project finance community development facilitators to strengthen the current local government structure. A special effort would be made to work with institutions familiar with participatory development and to train local officials in community development approaches. In addition during the early years of the proposed project, assistance would be provided to strengthen local capacity to carry out this approach through short-term training in community based planning for community leaders and technical agencies at the kecamatan and village levels. 5.10 During negotiations, the GOI Delegation expressed the view that some effort should be made in the project to foster the growth of grassroots community development organizations (CDOs). Budget Procedures 5.14 Project activities would be financed in accordance with existing GOI procedures for financing Bank-assisted projects. Counterpart funds for project activities would be provided under the budget of the Ministry of Agriculture for Component C. Funds for Components B and C would be from "On-Top" funds financed through the budget of the Ministry of Home Affairs and from the provincial and Kabupaten development budgets (APBD TK I and TK II). Budget allocations for project activities would be based on consolidated annual work programs agreed among project implementation agencies and BAPPEDA at the provincial level. The budgeting process under the proposed project would comprise the following steps: (a) the provincial BAPPEDAs would review the work programs proposed at local levels and as described in para 3.15 and prepare consolidated provincial work plans and draft budgets; (b) the provincial work plans and draft budgets would be sent to the National Project Secretariat for review and consolidation and thereafter submitted to BAPPENAS, AARD, MoHA and the provincial and Kabupaten authorities in August of each year for incorporation in their annual budget proposals; (c) the consolidated work plans and cost estimates would be forwarded to the Bank by October 31 of each year for review; and
 38 (d) the final budget proposals based on the agreed work plan would be forwarded to the Bank before December 31 of each project year. 5.15 To ensure that adequate funds would be provided for planned project activities, assurances were obtained from GOI at negotiations that GOI would furnish to the Bank for its review and comments: (a) not later than October 31 each year, a consolidated work program and cost estimates for the following fiscal year; and (b) by December 31 each year, coordinated budget proposals for the provincial work programs agreed with the Bank. Monitoring and Evaluation and Performance Indicators 5.16 Given the scale of community-based activities and the decentralized project management structure proposed for the project, close monitoring will be an essential feature of the project to permit continuous evaluation of project progress and to propose measures to ensure effective and efficient implementation. The M&E system would be similar to that designed for the proposed Nusa Tenggara Area-based Agriculture Development Project (NTAADP) and would include impact analysis for the main agricultural activities: village irrigation, dryland farming, livestock distribution, and other local community initiatives, in addition to the regular reports on financial and physical progress. Participation of women and youth in the various project activities will be monitored in the M&E program. 5.17 The first level of monitoring reports would be from Kabupaten level PIMNPROs to the Provincial Project Secretariat. These reports would be prepared quarterly and used to respond immediately to any problems encountered in implementing the project activity and also to elicit any technical help that may be necessary from the higher level technical agencies (provincial or central). The quarterly reports would be discussed with Bank Supervision missions. The second level of monitoring would be on the physical, environmental and financial progress of the project through mandated reporting forms from the implementing agencies varying according to the source of funding but updated at least every semester. The third level would seek to provide simple quantitative feedback on the performance of the project's major activities through impact indicators collected regularly and updated yearly to provide a data base for evaluating the financial, economic and social impact of project interventions on target beneficiaries. The fourth and final method would be rapid appraisal monitoring. This method is recommended as: (a) a means of direct interaction with the target population; and (b) a useful management tool to achieve coordination among the implementing agencies. Rapid appraisal should be conducted once a year at the Kabupaten level with representation from the Kabupaten Dinas, kecamatan staff, participating CDOs and the provincial BAPPEDA office. A consultant will be financed in each of the two provinces to set up and manage the monitoring process. 5.18 The proposed evaluation system has been designed to evaluate project outcomes in relation to the project objectives. A three tiered system would be used consisting of:
 39 (a) an initial inventory or data base on income and production information at the provincial and Kabupaten levels, building on the data gathered during project preparation; (b) a mid-term review after two years of project life to review progress, identify management and technical constraints, assess development impact and recommend adjustments in project design, as appropriate; and (c) a final review at project completion to evaluate the direct impact of the project on target groups and the effectiveness of the organizational structure and management system used in the project, and to draw conclusions for future projects. 5.19 Details on the proposed project performance indicators are given in Table 5.1. This is a comprehensive list discussed during negotiations which Government agreed to monitor. It was however agreed that a few key indicators from the above list will be selected during early supervision for close monitoring though Government indicated that given the new approach in this project, it would like to monitor as many f the indicators as possible. Bank Supervision 5.20 As the project is geographically dispersed and involves a novel approach to providing services to the rural population, the Bank should schedule supervision missions initially at least twice a year, starting off with two main project launch workshops in the two provinces and mini workshops in each Kabupaten. In general, the fall supervision missions will concentrate on the work programs and budgets for the following years and the spring missions on the results achieved in the field during the preceding rainy season. A mid-term review is also programmed for early 1999 even though each supervision mission would review project progress and consider necessary adjustments. An assurance was obtained from GOI during negotiations that a mid-term review report would be furnished to the Bank by March 31, 1999, for review and discussion with GOI by May 31, 1999. The Bank would rely to the extent possible on the Bank's Resident Mission staff (RSI) to interact continuously with the central and local project agencies and to undertake quick field visits to provide implementation assistance as necessary. A supervision plan for the project is at Annex 7. It details the mix of specialties and frequency and duration of missions needed to ensure adequate supervision by the Bank. In addition, RSI would conduct ex-post reviews of works completed and goods supplied at the rate of about two staff-weeks per year.
