PROJECT BENEFITS, AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION, MARKETING AND FARM INCOMES Project Benefits 6.1 The project would increase smallholder productivity and incomes, and raise the capacity of the local government agencies and village institutions to provide agricultural services to farmers and to promote community participation in development. The project, together with others, would also support and supplement GOI's ongoing efforts to improve the standards of living in the country's eastern islands and thus reduce regional income disparities. The main benefits are categorized below (see Annex -, Table - for further details): (a) direct impact on target beneficiaries through increased agricultural production and incomes, support for farming systems research, and improved rural infrastructure, especially roads. Because of the dense network of demonstration activities to be financed under the project, at least over 80 percent of the rural population (180,000 households) would be exposed to the project's activities. Cumulatively, over 100,000 households (or about 45 percent of the households) would directly benefit from project financing for either demonstration or replication of one or the other of the interventions under Component A (irrigation, dryland farming, treecrop rehabilitation, cattle distribution, and houseplot improvements, chicken vaccination, community initiatives, etc.). The village revolving credit program as well the introduction of better production technology generated by research (Component C), improvement of agricultural support services, and redistribution of breeding cattle, would further increase the number of beneficiaries beyond those estimated above, after the project ends; and (b) improved capacity of local planning and technical agencies to plan, appraise, monitor and execute multi-sectoral development programs and to correct program implementation whether the program is locally or externally financed. Civil servants and local government staff from the two provinces would receive short-term training and gain practical experience from the project to plan better for future development, improve future utilization of development resources and replicate the experience of the project in other areas. Agricultural Production 6.2 The impact of project activities on agricultural production has been analyzed based on different farm models that represent the farming typologies of the two provinces. Two farm model typologies were used for irrigated production, three for dryland farming, three for house gardening and two for treecrop rehabilitation.
 45 6.3 Farm Models Analyses. The impact of the project on production in irrigated agriculture have been based on two farm model types representing some 20,300 farms, at full development, with an average size of 0.5 ha irrigated land on some 203 farmer- managed village irrigation systems. For dryland agriculture, estimates are based on three farm model types representing some 52,000 farms at full development (PYIO) with an average size of 0.75 ha rainfed land. It has further been assumed that some 10 percent of the irrigated farms and up to 50 percent of the dryland farms would take up livestock keeping under the project by acquiring breeding cattle. Also, three farm model types covering some 8,800 farm households were reviewed to analyze the expected to increase in the production from home gardens. 6.4 Though assumptions underlying the farm models have been made as realistic as possible, the selected models are obviously simplifications of diverse situations existing in the field. Soil and water conditions in the project areas and cultural preferences of the people are the determinant factors in the choice of farming systems. The selected models obscure large variations in climatic conditions and productive potentials in the two provinces, between different areas of the same province and within islands. Also, there will be large differences in the time periods farmers will need to adopt improved cultivation practices, in some cases continuing beyond the project horizon and necessitating the making of assumptions for the purpose of quantifying project benefits. The models however are derived from current cultivation practices in Southeast and Central Sulawesi and capture the essentials of the prospects for improving agriculture in the two provinces. Generally, a conservative stance has been maintained for the projections of future production. Though full development is not expected until PYIO in terms of areas replicated (adopted), we leveled off adoption in terms of area at PY7 for purposes of our economic analysis. 6.5 Improvements in Productivity. Yield increases are assumed to derive from farmers adopting improved water management and improved technology packages in the form of higher yielding seed varieties, modern inputs and better cultural practices. The following assumptions were made regarding productivity improvements under the project: (a) In the village irrigation program the project will not finance any physical improvements to the schemes (diversion weirs, field canals, etc.) since these are already being made under GOI's ongoing Village Irrigation Improvement program (PID). The latter program however will not finance any agricultural improvements on completed schemes. The village irrigation model used here therefore assumes that the present project would follow up on the infrastructure improvements with field demonstrations and extension of improved production practices (HYV seeds, fertilizers, etc.), organization of farmer and water user groups, plus financing (through the village credit scheme) for replication. The project interventions are expected to result in additional increases in the yields of the two main crops paddy (from an estimated average 4.0 tons to 5.5 ton/ha) and soybeans (from 0.8 tons to 1.2 tons/ha).
 46 Cropping intensity is assumed to increase from 1.0 to 1.10. A Table on the rate of adoption of the technology is in Annex 1 Table 1. (b) In the dryland production program, the crops currently produced (without project) are upland rice and beans (mungbeans, soybeans, etc.) with a cropping intensity of about 91 percent. The technology to be introduced under the project would permit farmers to diversify into tree crops (mainly cashew, fruit trees), fodder/fuel trees, and grass. Since the technology aims at helping farmers intensify their production and become sedentary, the upland rice would be replaced in the rotation by maize. They would also be encouraged to intensify food crop cultivation. Three farm model types have been used (Annex I Table A3) and these models assumes an increase in average cropping intensity to about 141 percent. This increase would occur gradually, allowing sufficient time for farmers to test the recommended new practices. Maize yields would increase from 1.5 to about 2.0 to 2.2 tons/ha for farmers who would adopt the application of basic fertilizer dosages (Models 2 & 3) but only about 1.6 ton/ha for those who would not (Model 1). Mungbean yields would increase from 600 to 700 kg (Model 1) or to 900 kg/ha (Models 2 &3). Cashew trees would start yielding 1 kg dry raw nuts/tree from year 6, increasing to about 7.5 kg nuts/tree by year 11 (Model 2); the average farmer would have about 3 3 trees. A Table on the rate of adoption of the dryland technology is in Annex 1 Table 2. (c) In the Treecrop Rehabilitation program, there would be two basic types of activities: rehabilitation of existing overgrown cashew (in general not shaded); and rehabilitation of cacao farms (shaded by coconut or other trees or bananas). For cashew, it is recommended to reduce the number of mature trees to some 33 trees/ha and plant foodcrops in between, such as corn and mungbeans. Alternatively when high quality cashew seedlings are available (about Year 5 or 6 of project), they could be planted to replace the ones which have been cut out, which in turn will replace the oldest trees after some 4 to 6 years. For purposes of our farm model analyses however, we have used only the first approach (Annex I Table A4). For the cacao model (Annex 1 Table A5), it is recommended to apply proper pruning techniques to improve tree shapes, fruit bearing, crop sanitation and ventilation and improve the quality of the shade trees by planting lamtoro and gamal trees. For cacao, yields are estimated to increase from 350 kg/ha in the without project situation to about 800kg/ha five years after rehabilitation (starting from 250kg) and for cashew, yields are expected to go up from 350 kg/ha to 700 kg/ha in Year 5 (starting from some 200kg/ha). In addition the inter-cropped maize is expected to yield the equivalent of 1.8 tons/ha and mungbeans about 700 kg/ha. A Table on the rate of adoption of the treecrop rehabilitation technology is in Annex 1 Table 3 (d) The house garden model (Annex 1 Table A6) assumes that those adopting the program would replace cassava cultivation with some beans/vegetables and also plant mangoes, jackfruit, vanilla, ginger and lamtoro. Modest increases in food crops (maize and beans) and treecrop production are expected from use of manure, cash inputs and better cultivation practices.
 47 (e) For farmers receiving livestock, improved cattle feeding practices and better health care are expected to (a) increase cattle birth rates from about 70 to 80 percent, and (b) decrease mortality rates from 15 percent to 8 percent for animals under one year of age and from 3 percent to 2 percent for animals over three years. For the poultry vaccination program, in order to eliminate the problem posed by vaccines requiring refrigeration, the project is to introduce a new technology of a heat resistant vaccine (the V4 strain), now available in Indonesia. A community-based system relying on the existing women network organizations, PKK, would be used to support the vaccination program to control Newcastle disease among village chickens. 6.6 Incremental Production. Applying the assumptions in the farm model typologies above to areas that can be covered in the project under proposals for demonstration and replication activities, would lead to a direct project induced incremental annual production at full development, equivalent to about 8,800 tons of paddy, 41,300 tons of maize, 12,300 tons of beans (soybeans and mungbeans), 2,960 tons of raw cashew nuts, 5,600 tons of cacao, about 1,000 tons of fruits and smaller production of vanilla and ginger. The cattle distribution program and associated investments in animal health are expected to add annually about 1,260 head of cattle (year 10). In practice the composition of incremental production is likely to be far more diverse since farmers are essentially free to cultivate what crops they want and for which there is demand. Crops that are likely to be cultivated include coffee, different types of beans, more soybeans and fruit trees than anticipated, and groundnuts. The value of the incremental production at full development would be equivalent to over US$22.5 million per year (Annex 1 Table Al). Farm Incomes. 6.7 Table 6.1 gives a summary of the expected farm incomes from the farm models analyzed. Net farm incomes are expected to increase as a result of improvements to the irrigated and dryland cropping systems, the treecrop rehabilitation program, cattle and poultry keeping, and intensified home gardening - either separately or in combination. In general therefore farmers adopting the proposed interventions are expected to obtain substantial increases in net incomes, from their combined farming activities.

ECONOMIC JUSTIFICATION, IMPACT ASSESSMENTS AND RISKS Project Alternatives 7.1 Several alternative approaches to project design were considered during project preparation, with the following being the key ones: (a) Sector/centrally managed project. One main alternative approach to project design would normally be a project designed centrally with components in the provinces. In general however, these central-based sector projects have not attempted to design operations to fit local constraints, but rather project areas have been selected to fit project design. Such a central approach, for small resource poor and remote provinces, such as those in the proposed project, often leads to a general lack of balance in investments either between sectors or between regions and little integration in programs. The regional approach adopted here has allowed for a better local focus and review of the technical, institutional, and incentive constraints of the project area and a project design adapted to each area's conditions (b) Regional coverage. Government's initial objective was to prepare one regional development project covering at least seven provinces in the eastern islands that it considered the poorest (Southeast and Central Sulawesi, East and West Nusa Tenggara, East Timor, Maluku and Irian Jaya). In order to adapt project design to specific regions and keep implementation and supervision arrangements simple, the Bank and GOI eventually agreed to prepare separate projects for the different areas. The Bank agreed to assist Government prepare three of these projects covering one project for the two Nusa Tenggara provinces, one for Maluku and the third for Central and Southeast Sulawesi. Other donors (ADB and AUSAID) are helping Government with activities in Irian Jaya and East Timor. (c) Sector Coverage. Regional authorities were interested, during preparation, in including activities from non-agricultural sectors. The Bank agreed with Government that though other sector activities are important, implementation experience of integrated rural development activities financed by the Bank has shown that such projects are overly complex to manage and their poor performance has been associated with project complexity and lack of flexibility. The project scope was therefore limited to agriculture and associated infrastructure development (roads), excluding sectors such as health care and education. It was stressed however that though the project focus is on agriculture, it is expected to complement other alternative non-agricultural activities being financed by Government (e.g. through IDT), other donors
 50 (Bank in Kabupaten Roads, Water Supply, Education, urban infrastructure, etc.) and private individuals in trade and processing, (d) Project Components. Several proposed sub-components for agricultural area development were dropped for various reasons. Land titling was not included because on balance comprehensive national coverage reflecting national priorities is preferred over fragmented regional coverage. Goat distribution was dropped as a sub-component because a large number of IDT village groups are already involved in goat distribution. Though construction of village irrigation structures was included during preparation, it was eventually deleted because Government had just started a nationwide Village Irrigation Schemes Project (PID). The main fisheries activities that were being requested during preparation were additional fishing boats and outboard motors. This was however excluded because the Eastern Islands study"4 showed that increasing capitalization may be leading to rising and an unsustainable level of indebtedness of coastal fishing communities. Similarly earlier projects involving boat and outboard motor credits were not very successful and hence these were excluded. (e) Implementation Arrangements. The experience of NTASP and other donor- financed projects that directly involved the communities, has confirmed the importance of beneficiary participation in project implementation. Under the proposed project therefore, the kabupaten and lower level technical agencies would work closely together with area CDOs to organize farmers and further encourage beneficiary participation in the planning and implementation of all area-based schemes. Fiscal Implications and Cost Recovery 7.2 The agriculture development component that makes up over 80 percent of project cost would be implemented by the existing provincial and kabupaten technical services. The project would support the Dinas by training their staff, providing them with transport facilities and equipment, and paying allowances to facilitate effective implementation of all sub-components. None of these support measures would have fiscal implications beyond the project implementation period. There would be no recruitment of new staff except perhaps those to be contracted by CDOs as additional community development facilitators. 7.3 Since a few years ago, the Ministry of Agriculture transferred the operation and maintenance of the Rural Extension Centers (REC) and Animal Health Centers (Poskeswan) to the kabupaten governments. However these governments have not provided adequate financing for their operation. One of the objectives of the project 14 Eastern Islands Rural Sector Strategy Review, Yellow Cover Report, November 1994, Chap 5
 51 would be to make the existing RECs operational and convert them into multi-purpose extension facilities and training and meeting center for the field level extension agents, PPLs. A recent national study on decentralized study has confirmed that this is the approach of follow. Similarly the project would work to make the Poskeswans effective. For both the RECs and Poskeswans therefore, additional funding beyond what is currently provided will be required to make them operational and effective. The project would finance rehabilitation of the RECs and Poskeswans on condition that management plans would be prepared and implemented for them (para. 3.16) including agreement from the kabupaten concerned to pay the O&M costs of the facilities. Assurances to this effect were obtained during negotiations. In addition, assurances were obtained that fees would be charged to the users of the Poskeswan that would contribute to paying for the operating costs of the centers. 7.4 Farmers would be asked to contribute to the implementation of sub-components, such as roads and water infrastructure, usually in the form of labor. For the irrigated cropping, dryland cropping, treecrop rehabilitation, and homeplot improvements sub- components, the project provides for a revolving credit scheme (para ...) that would finance inputs for adopters. The research and extension components are by and large public goods and are not practically amenable to direct cost recovery. Poverty Impact 7.5 A major emphasis of the Eastem Islands Study was on identifying policies and activities that not only will promote agricultural growth but help reduce poverty in eastern Indonesia. The proposed project is one such activity that has been identified as a result of the recommendations of the sector study. One of the main criteria for selecting project areas and activities was to reach a large number of households below or near the poverty line and hence implicit in the objectives of the project is poverty alleviation. Thus the main Kecamatans with high incidence of poverty were targeted for project intervention. Incomes of the population in the target areas are generally low and hence the expected increases in household incomes demonstrated in the farm budget analyses should contribute to reduce poverty in these areas. Thus if estimates of the proposed project's quantifiable benefits for households, which show doubling of incomes for dryland and treecrop rehabilitation (US$135 to about US$280, and US$230 to about US$470 equivalent respectively) and a 50 percent increase for households doing irrigated cropping, are realized then the impact of the project on poverty reduction should be significant. The project is also likely to generate substantial, but as yet not quantifiable, benefits for the people in the targeted areas, such as better road access and improved availability of farm produce and farm inputs. Economic Analysis 7.6 Treatment of Components. The project's Economic Rate of Return (ERR) was estimated taking into account all project costs. Though research costs were added, no direct benefits were assigned to the component. The impact of research would be long-
 52 term in nature and would extend well beyond the project areas to the entire territories of the two Sulawesi provinces. Although calculating an ERR for the research component would be difficult, it would be possible to relate research cost to the size of the agricultural sector in the two provinces to estimate an ERR. The project's research component would cost about US$1.6 million over six years. This investment would generate an economic rate of return of more than 50 percent if it were to prompt a one- time 0.25 percent increase in agricultural production (a conservative assumption) in the two provinces from the third project year onwards. 7.7 No attempts were made to estimate separate ERRs for individual project components or for different productive sub-components because: (a) most components and sub-components are complementary, for example cropping and cattle keeping; and (b) there are no clear-cut ways to allocate the cost of supporting investments, e.g. road improvements, technical assistance and training, among the separate productive activities. The cost of "other local community initiatives" have been included in the calculations even though those activities and their benefits have not been identified as yet. 7.8 The economic prices for fertilizers were based on prices derived from World Bank international price projections. The economic prices (1995 constant) used for rice, maize, soybeans, and fertilizer were based on parity prices derived from World Bank international market projections for these commodities, adjusted for east Indonesia transport costs. The economic price of cashew was based on a recent FAO study which projected economic farm gate prices for this commodity in the same provinces. The economic prices of mungbeans and livestock were equated with local market prices as production of these commodities in the target areas is not import substituting. No discount factor for labor costs was used as most project areas are not densely populated and economic wage levels are assumed to equal local market wage rates of Rp. 2,500 per day. A 20 year planning horizon was used in the analysis. 7.9 Rate of Return. The ERR of the project has been estimated at 21 percent. A summary of the cost and benefit streams are at Annex 6, Table 2. 7.10 Sensitivity Analysis. If some of the risks alluded to in para. 7.18 were to materialize, the effect on the project's ERR would be as indicated below: (a) delay of benefits (but not of costs) due to institutional or technical implementation problems: (i) by I year: ERR 16 percent; and (ii) by 2 years: ERR 9.7 percent (b) decrease in gross benefit levels due to overestimation of local governments' capacity to provide adequate project follow-up support, or because of

Since there are sometimes labor shortages during peak agricultural periods, we tested the ERR for the possibility that the higher level of agricultural activities could lead to an increase in the opportunity cost of labor. If project activities lead to an increase in the opportunity cost of labor from the current Rp 2,500 per day to Rp 3,500 per day the project's ERR would fall from 21 percent to 17.0 percent. Environmental Impact Assessment 7.12 Environmental Screening. Proposed project interventions were screened during preparation and an environmental analysis done of the different types of activities to assess whether the proposed activities individually or cumulatively would result in any significant impact on the environment and what environmental management procedures to put in place. The main conclusions of the assessment are summarized below. 7.13 The assessment reviewed the environmental laws and procedures existing in Indonesia and concluded that the project represents a category of activity that does not clearly conform to any of the screening profiles in Indonesian environmental law. This is because the project is multi-sectoral, and is designed to be implemented at the district level in the form of numerous small, dispersed activities. In order to assess how project activities fit into the environmental framework, the assessment sought to answer three major questions: (i) whether any of the proposed categories of activities individually or cumulatively result in significant impacts?; (ii) if the project taken as a whole would produce significant cumulative impacts on the region?; and (iii) who is responsible for the environmental management program under SAADP? 7.14 In trying to answer the above questions individual project activities were evaluated to determine if they will produce significant impacts. The following characteristics of the
 54 project area and the project design were reviewed and considered relevant to the management of potential adverse environmental effects of the project: (a) Physical Environment - Both provinces, but especially Central Sulawesi are mountainous, with flat, arable land at a premium despite low overall population density. The mountains are geologically young, with steep slopes, and highly erodible soils in many areas. Settlements are clustered near the coast and in narrow inter- montane valleys. Both provinces are predominated by infertile soils overlying limestone and ultra-basic rocks. Southeast Sulawesi does contain large areas of alluvial and rolling plains that could be made more productive, but rainfall is limited in these areas". (b) Land Classification/Protected Areas - Large portions of both provinces are within the national forest estate, and a fair percentage of the forest land is classified in restrictive use types such as Protection Forest or various types of natural area reserves The island of Sulawesi is very biodiverse with high levels of endemism because it forms a transition zone between the Asian and Australian bio-genetic realms. Central Sulawesi contains three large and important protected areas: Lore Lindu National Park, Morowali Strict Nature Reserve, and Togian Islands Strict Nature Reserve. Both provinces contain a number of smaller protected areas (c) Roads - Access to many of the areas in which project activities will be implemented is difficult due to the poorly developed road network, making screening and monitoring more difficult. (d) Social - Rural populations are in general more isolated than in other provinces, and have not been exposed to some of the production technologies being proposed under the agriculture development component (A). Project participants will therefore require greater than normal assistance to implement these activities in a technically and environmentally sound manner. Community institutions are weak in many villages because they are composed of relatively recent migrants from elsewhere in Sulawesi or other Indonesian islands.; and (e) Institutions - District and provincial government agencies in the two provinces are in general underdeveloped compared with their counterparts in western Indonesia, and have not had much experience implementing large projects or managing the environmental Environmental Impacts 7.15 The proposed activities do not pose an inherent threat to the environment, particularly if implemented at low intensity levels and in widely scattered locations. During appraisal Government decided that the villages and sub-districts adjacent to the Lore Lindu National Park (Lore Utara, Lore Selatan, Kulawi and the southern part of Biromaru) that had initially been considered for inclusion in the project, be excluded since a proposed integrated area development project to be financed by the Asian Development Bank would cover these areas. None of the other sub-districts or villages bordering the main national parks either in Southeast or Central Sulawesi is in the project area and hence project activities would have practically no impact on the Parks and Nature Reserves. The main project activities are analyzed below in terms of their inherent potential to produce impacts. 7.16 Crop Development Program. The various activities in this component would include: (a) Irrigated Cropping Technology: This activity involves providing training, tools, and inputs to help farmers increase rice, soy bean and mungbean yields from existing irrigated fields. The proposed project's intervention in the schemes is limited to demonstrations of improved cropping and livestock practices, including assistance for production and use of improved seeds. It does not involve the physical upgrading of irrigation facilities which is being done before the start of the proposed project, or will be improved simultaneously under Government's village irrigation scheme. Potential adverse environmental impacts could result from improper handling or application of pesticides or fertilizers resulting in water contamination on-site and off-site, or health risks to farmers applying the chemicals. The potential adverse environmental impacts related to improper handling and application of pesticides and fertilizers will be mitigated by appropriate training of extension agents and by insuring that the agents pass on this information to farmers. In association with the Directorate General of Foodcrops integrated pest management techniques would be introduced. (b) Dryland Farming Systems Development: Improved techniques for dryland cropping on sloping land can have the positive environmental effects of conserving soil and water while producing a wider variety of crops. These positive effects can be negated if the chosen techniques are not suited to soil and slope conditions, or if the techniques are not properly implemented. Farmers are not generally familiar with these techniques, and therefore the environmental outcome rests on the quantity and quality of extension assistance provided to them. The mitigation plan would be similar to that for the irrigation program and would involve improved training and awareness programs. (c) Home Garden Intensification: This activity is environmentally neutral with respect to the natural environment, and potentially positive with respect to human nutrition
 56 7.17 The Livestock Development Program covers: (a) The Improvement and Operation of Animal Health Clinics: This activity has a potentially positive environmental effect by reducing the incidence of disease in the livestock population. (b) Vaccination of Chickens Against Newcastle Disease: This activity is environmentally positive in terms of limiting the incidence of this disease. (c) Cattle Distribution: This activity poses some inherent risk to the environment that can be mitigated by appropriate planning, training, execution and monitoring. Potential impacts to be avoided are: 1) the spread of disease by moving sick animals to areas free of disease; 2) damage to forest areas from free-roaming animals or forest clearance to open grazing areas; and 3) run-off ofwaste from holding areas. The mitigation plan involves a number of steps including; inspecting cattle for disease prior to shipment; ensuring that recipient villages and groups have adequate land and feed within existing village lands; and training recipient farmers to control animals, to avoid plowing steep hillsides, and to use manure for fertilizer. This component will be monitored frequently for compliance. 7.18 Improvement of Farm to Market Roads. This sub-component has the greatest potential among all SAADP activities to cause adverse environmental impacts. Potential impacts are: 1) improper construction or alignment can lead to soil erosion from the road surface or cut and fill slopes; 2) improperly sized or constructed culverts or bridges can impair surface water flow, especially in wet land areas; and 3) improper siting would provide access and may cause disturbance to protected areas. These risks are however reduced because the roads are generally short and would follow existing alignments. However, risks stemming from improper construction are increased by the fact that construction will be carried out by villagers rather than experienced contractors. Site screening, construction supervision, and monitoring are required as mitigation measures. A project manual similar to the one being used for the Village Infrastructure Project will be used to guide villages through the road design and construction process, and to insure that proper construction standards are used. In addition a screening process would be put in place whereby the individual roads proposed for funding each year are evaluated to ensure that their siting would not cause significant adverse impacts. 7.19 Institutional Measures. In order to ensure that the appropriate monitoring procedures are put in place and that environmental concerns become part of routine decision-making, environmental management activities would be integrated into the institutional structure of the project. Environmental screening will especially be imbedded into the annual proposal review and budgeting process. An Environmental Specialist will be recruited for 3 months during the first year of the project to formulate Environmental Management and Monitoring Plan templates, develop environmental training modules, make recommendations for detailed institutional arrangements, and assist the project
 57 managers to operationalize environment related activities. As part of its annual program review process, the Provincial Coordination Committee (PCC) would ensure the screening of all project proposals, making sure that the districts are formulating and implementing Environmental Management and Monitoring Plans as necessary in accordance with the templates and regulations. The PCC can ask appropriately qualified institutions, such as the Environmental Studies Center of the provincial university, to help it in the screening process. The PCC would be responsible for implementing environmental training, and monitoring the implementation of any management plans that may be necessary. Project Management Units at district level would be responsible for ensuring that: 1) the recommendations made by the screeners are incorporated into the annual proposal review process; 2) the technical agencies have properly formulated and are following any necessary environmental management and monitoring plans; and 3) the extension agents/ road engineers advising farmers/communities are trained to advise their clients how to plan and implement project activities in an environmentally sound manner. Impact on the Social and Cultural Environment. 7.20 The preparation process has included a social assessment study to establish an initial socio-economic and cultural picture of the project areas and beneficiaries; assess the impact of project activities on the local population and other stakeholders; examine and find solutions for the local perceived constraints to agricultural development; and design programs to meet aspirations of the local population. The assessment study recognizes that though the two provinces are inhabited by diverse ethnic and linguistic groups no serious social or cultural tensions have been reported in the target areas. Program design and implementation would however need to be flexible and be adjusted to local conditions. The principal conclusion of the assessment was that for the project to be sustainable communities would have to participate fully in the planning and management process. Project design therefore provides for this direct involvement of the local communities in planning and implementation of project activities. The assessment study also reviewed the possible impact of the different agricultural activities on the socio-economic situation of the target areas. Though farmers in the project areas still adopt the cultural framework associated with subsistence agriculture, it is not anticipated that any induced socio- economic change would result in any deterioration of current social or cultural values. Adoption of new technology by the project participants would be on a voluntary basis. 7.21 In order to maintain the high degree of community involvement required, the project will finance community facilitators, to be recruited through CDOs. The latter are expected to play a key role in identifying and implementation of operations under the community based initiatives program, in farmer organization and training, and helping farmer groups manage their revolving credit. For this purpose it has been agreed that a draft standard-type agreement would be drawn up between the provincial authorities (Bappeda TK I) in both provinces and reputable CDO(s) for the supply and management of community development facilitators. The draft standard-type agreement would be discussed during negotiations and the agreement signed before disbursements are made on the community based initiatives program.
 58 7.22 The project involves no resettlement and does not involve land acquisition for any of the activities proposed either for field demonstration or the infrastructure components. Demonstrations will be on farmers' fields to be managed by farmers themselves and road construction would consist of upgrading of existing roads and tracks with no need for land acquisition. Though the project would support local people indigenous to the two provinces (as opposed to migrants) it does not involve any "indigenous" or "tribal" peoples. None of the target areas appear to include locations of major monuments of archaeological significance. Cultural habits and customs reflect a pattern of life that centers on small scale farming activities. The project interventions would not change this basic lifestyle, but aim to create a more sustainable pattern of land use and provide technological options for improvement of agriculture and other economic activities. Impact on Women and Youth 7.23 Reviewing rural conditions in Sulawesi confirms the central role played by women in agricultural activities. Women and youth are involved in most aspects of the agricultural production cycle from weeding and planting to harvesting and marketing in addition to household tasks. Their responsibilities appear to be a lot more in foodcrop production and house gardening than in estate crop production even though in the latter area they do most of the harvesting, processing and marketing. They are normally responsible for small livestock (chickens and ducks), less involved with goats and other small ruminants and not usually involved in the husbandry of larger animals (cattle and water buffaloes). The family concept appears to be very strong however and hence, women are reported to be responsible for family finances. 7.24 The approach to be adopted regarding the different roles of men, women and youth in the household, as well as in the production systems, is to make them equal beneficiaries of all activities. Since the focus of project support would be on the household, project interventions would need to address the specific needs of different household members. Gender disaggregated data would have to be collected to obtain a better picture of the role of various groups in the community and the household. The project includes support for activities that are traditionally the responsibility of women, such as home gardening, poultry vaccination, produce processing, marketing, small enterprise development, etc. - the latter activities through the local initiatives component. Other activities that can positively impact on women and youth also include provision of credit, seeds and other inputs. Providing opportunities for increasing women and youth's involvement in agricultural development, consistent with their active role in the sector, will enhance their contribution to development. Gender sensitivity training for extension workers, project staff, and community leaders will enhance their skills to tap this important human resource and improve the participation of women and youth groups in the project. Participation of women in the various project activities would be monitored in the M&E program.
 59 Project Risks 7.25 Three risks have been identified and taken into consideration in project formulation and design: (a) Capacity of the Local Government Agencies. Sub-standard capabilities and lack of experience and resources of these agencies could lead to delays in achieving the implementation targets. The experience of NTASP, as indicated in its ICR, has however shown that it is possible to work with inexperienced local and provincial level institutions, strengthen them in their respective roles in planning, implementing, and coordinating decentralized and multi-sectoral interventions while at the same time providing useful services to farmers to improve their productivity. The ICR of NTASP has also confirmed that the focus on implementation through the existing administration structure at the provincial, kabupaten and kecamatan levels, and a systematic effort for using project area CDOs, are important and relevant approaches to ensure adequate project impact. To minimize the risk, the project includes several training activities for agency staff and community leaders at project start and employment of technical assistance to assist in project implementation. Operating means are also provided to ensure that staff are able to make frequent field visits to plan and implement activities with farmers. The volume, scale and complexity of project interventions would be planned from year to year on the basis of a realistic assessment of institutional capacities, both in the local Dinas and the participating CDOs. (b) Organizational structure and implementation arrangements. Institutional and organizational complexity of the proposed project is another risk and may, together with weaknesses of local technical agencies (referred to above), cause implementation delays. This risk is reduced by defining clearly the responsibilities of the various agencies involved in the project implementation at all levels and using the existing structures and coordination arrangements which would help project execution. Technical assistance would also help improve the project management during the early stages of implementation. (c) Delays and possible abuse of the bottom-up process. The third risk involves possible delays and even abuse of the bottom-up planning process that is to be used to implement the agriculture activities. Local govenmment officials have been used to implementing central sectoral operations for which instructions are issued from the center. The proposed approach is therefore novel and may take some time to implement. This risk is reduced by including CDOs, with experience in community participation, in the farmer organization and planning program. Also the first project year will be used for training of staff and community leaders and to explain the project concept to them and to start field level activities only in the second year.

 62 ANNEX 1 INDONESIA SULAWESI AGRICULTURAL AREA DEVELOPMENT PROJECT Implementation of Agricultural Area Development A. Village Irrigation Background 1. There are a large number of village irrigation schemes in the project provinces which have been established by the farmers without government assistance. Yields of paddy in these schemes average about 3.0 tons/ha due to the use of low quality seeds, low levels of fertilizer, and poor management of water. The Government launched in January 1995 an ambitious three-year national program to upgrade village irrigation schemes covering some 900,000 ha, or about 90 percent of all schemes believed to exist in the country. The program is known as Improvement of Village Irrigation Schemes (PID), and sometimes also referred to as Village Irrigation Crash Program. The objective of the program is to quickly improve diversion structures and canals in the majority of the country's village irrigation systems (including those located in the two project provinces) and thereby increase Indonesia's paddy production by about one million ton. The works are designed and executed by the Public Works Department, either under contract or force account. It is anticipated that this program will help upgrade the irrigation infrastructure in most of the schemes currently exploited by farmers. Additional assistance is however required to successfully transfer improved production technology to farmers to achieve maximum economic yields. Proposed Program 2. The objective of the project intervention is to transfer appropriate production technology for intensification of rice and soybeans/mungbeans cultivation through demonstrations of technology packages in village irrigation schemes in the target areas. Demonstrations (3.0 ha. per village irrigation scheme for two years) would be carried out on farmers' fields with the active participation of farmer groups. Project assistance would be provided in the form of extension advice, training and provision of seeds, inputs and agricultural tools. 3. Typically the 3 ha demonstration would be established in adjacent 0.5 ha farm plots involving

Food Crops Seed Multiplication Background 7. The provision of high quality seeds is an important part of the development program for food crops production. The Government of Indonesia, since the introduction of the BIMAS (mass guidance) in the early sixties, has considered seed production to be one of the five major aspects in foodcrops production improvement. Since its first launching in the mid- Pelita I period (1971), the seed multiplication program has been supported by various Government policies on seed certification. However, the implementation of such policies has faced major constraints at provincial and kabupaten level, so that the availability of extension seeds at the farming level is not sufficient, in particular in the more remote areas in Indonesia, away from Java and Bali. 8. Therefore, in supporting the development of Sulawesi Tenggara and Sulawesi Tengah, especially in the foodcrops production program with the introduction of improved technologies and locally adapted varieties, the production of sufficient high quality seeds for farmers use, is very critical. The Kabupaten Seed Multiplication Centers for Food Crops (BBP) are a critical link between the Main Seed Production Center at provincial level (BBU) and the farmer seed growers. One of the setbacks of the Government's recent past foundation seed delivery policies, was that most varieties were selected under Java conditions only, but approved for wider distribution. Fortunately, AARD and MOA now realize that different agro-ecological zones with different management requirements and pests and diseases, need different characteristics in the varieties. Varieties acceptable to Java, may not be good enough for other islands. 9. At present both the production of stock seed from the BBPs and extension seed from the Farmer Seed Growers provide less than half of the total seed requirements of farmers who now rely mainly on low yielding local and degenerated HYV varieties. Often the same seed is used in different seasons, while different varieties are required. Seed purity (durability) and viability are often below standard, resulting in poor germination and diminished yields. The Government's attention in seed supplies has been mainly on rice in the past. However for
 65 ANNEX 1 Sulawesi Tenggara and Tengah, other food crops such as maize, soybeans, mungbeans and peanuts are equally important in the dryland farming system. 10. Major constraints. The main constraints in the Indonesian seed industry, and on the outer islands in particular, include: * insufficient number of seed stations (private or public) in the country to produce and multiply breeders seed; * insufficient capacity and production of locally adapted, high quality provincial foundation (BBI) and kabupaten stock (BBP) seeds to supply farmer seed growers; * insufficient number of well trained extension seed producers/farmer seed growers; * inadequate and poor organization of the Seeds Control and Certification Stations (SCCS); * insufficient recognition by the farmer users of the importance of using locally adapted, high quality seeds and varieties in raising yields. 11. The overall constraint, however, seems to be the strong govemment control in the national seed production and delivery system, crowding out the private sector, and an unattractive remuneration for breeders rights and the private seed sector. Proposed Project intervention 12. Since there is no viable private seed sector yet, the project will facilitate the production of stock seeds at selected BBPs in the 8 project kabupatens, in order to supply sufficient high quality seeds to farmer seed growers. These growers in tum will produce the much needed improved extension (certified) seeds for the farmer users. 13. Kabupaten Seed Multiplication Centers (BBPs) for Food Crops. Dryland Farming System Development Background. 16. The productivity of the prevailing smallholder systems of dryland agricultural production in the target areas is low as are farm incomes. In addition, the practice of shifting cultivation in some areas is leading to degradation of land resources. One of the most important results that came from the Farming Systems Research program of the Nusa Tenggara Agricultural Services Project (NTASP) was the necessity to stress the use of conservation farming techniques in the fragile soils of eastern Indonesia and to link these techniques to other farming activities such as livestock production. Because population densities of Southeast and Central Sulawesi are still low, there has been a tendency to assume that there is an abundance of unused land and that therefore, the need for conservation practices to preserve soil fertility is not as important as in overcrowded Java. However given the fragile and less productive soils of the East, it is in general even more important there to practice conservation farming to preserve the shallow topsoils. Technology packages for dryland farming systems development have been tested in many parts of Indonesia including in some parts of Sulawesi and can be promoted in the target areas. Some commnon forms of dryland farming techniques are the following: Alley Cropping (Tanaman Lorong); Contour Ridge Terracing (Teras Guludan); Cover Crops; Living Fences (Pagar Hidup); and Bench
 67 ANNEX 1 Terraces (Teras Bangku). In addition to these techniques promoting soil conservation, they have the added advantage of providing additional fodder for animal feed and producing fuelwood. Project Intervention 17. The objective of the intervention would be to introduce improved dryland farming systems technology packages to increase farmer incomes and reduce negative environmental effects from traditional cultivation systems. Diffusion of farming systems development technology packages to area farmers would be carried out through provision of assistance to farmers interested in adopting the technology. Project assistance would be provided for demonstration, seedling/seed production, and replication. The main technique to be promoted would be aDley cropping of lamtoro/gamal-vetiver/king grass, inter-cropping of food crops with improved seeds and minimum level of inputs, and establishment of low density plantings of cashew or other appropriate perennial crops. Nurseries to produce seedlings would be implemented by the farmer groups with inputs being provided by the project. The farmers would provide all labor without compensation. 18. Demonstrations.  73 ANNEX 1 G. Livestock Development Background 32. Total livestock population in the two project areas consists of 1.2 million cattle, 56,000 buffalo, 340,000 small ruminants, approximately a quarter million pigs, and nearly 10 million native poultry. Other important species include waterfowl and pigeons. Livestock contributes approximately $ 5.5 million (4.4%) to regional GDP. The southern peninsula (South Sulawesi) is a major cattle growing area where approximately 20% of the households depend on cattle production as a major source of income, either derived from breeding, fattening, draught labor and, indirectly, manure. Many of the agricultural areas in Central and Southeast Sulawesi, however, have a low livestock population, leaving the rural population, without the buffer of livestock ownership, more vulnerable to the risk of rainfed agriculture. Lessons from past Distribution Programs. 33. Livestock distribution started with the transmigration programs in the late seventies. The major objective were to provide farmers with production and security means, by correcting the two major market failures in transmigration areas e.g. lack of livestock markets, and the lack of credit. Livestock were provided through an in kind credit systems whereby farmers receive livestock and had to return two of the offspring within a given time period. Overall the program has been successful in the distribution. The major target animal has been cattle, but projects have also distributed goats as well as poultry. Overall the programs have been appreciated by farmers. The perceived benefits were: improved welfare and increased house hold security due to increased savings; increased productivity, production intensity and security from use of manure and draught power; regular income from calf fattening (young bulls 6-12 months). 34. A recent review of the livestock distribution programs showed a number of problems including: (i) bureaucratic delays in repayment in kind (e.g. farmers waiting till they can deliver calf, with associated risks), (ii) inadequate animal health and services especially in remote areas, (iii) lack of adequate feed in the dry season (mainly in drier areas), and (iv) the lack of knowledge about animal husbandry of recipient farmers (and the lack of appropriate extension help). In some areas farmers also complained about the lack of breeding service and/or access to bulls. In addition most distribution systems have worked very much top down and have rarely involved farmers in the planning and processing. 35. There exist some experience with livestock distribution in the region, most recently in an IFAD financed project that distributed livestock in a selected number of kabupaten both in Central and Southeast Sulawesi. Among the recognized problems especially in the area in previous distribution schemes was the lack of proper preparation of farmers, the lack of sufficient training and technical assistance/supervision, lack of animal health services and other institutional problems. The proposed project will draw on this experience but will be different especially with respect to a greater decentralization of decision making and management.

In addition, as part of the process of ensuring full repayment, villages with farmer groups or individuals having overdue loans may not be provided further grants. CDOs working in the project will assist in setting up the credit program and in training the credit committee to manage the credit.
 79 ANNEX 1 55. Livestock Revolving Credit. Some similar arrangements as the above input credit will be made to cover the livestock revolving credit scheme. Past experience seems to suggest that schemes that rely on the government technical agencies and BRI to police repayment and redistribution are not completely sustainable after projects are completed. Farmer groups and communities will play a more important role in managing the livestock credit than has been done in previous livestock revolving schemes (especially the IFAD financed projects). Even though BRI may be used as the channeling bank by virtue of its presence in more rural areas than any other Bank, it is proposed that the contract for the livestock credit be signed between the individual farmer and Kecamatan livestock committees 1/ to be set up (regrouping heads of villages). The livestock committees will be responsible for ensuring recuperation of the livestock credit and redistribution to farmers who have not yet received the cattle and who meet the criteria to receive it. In such a scheme, the role of BRI becomes that of an ordinary commercial bank. J. Farm Access Roads Background 56. Poor road access and lack of other social infrastructure are major constraints for the development of much of the eastem islands, including the two Sulawesi provinces. Many villages still are not connected by all-weather roads to the provincial and kabupaten road network and the condition of these district and provincial roads are also often poor. Existing roads are often damaged by rain causing transportation breakdowns between villages and markets. In the face of these needs, both the central and local Govemments have been allocating large proportions of their development budgets to the upgrading of public infrastructure. Improvement of transportation alone represented over 50 percent of regional development expenditures in both target provinces during the Repelita V period. Despite these past expenditures on road infrastructure, a recent OECF-financed study, entitled "Rural Areas Infrastructure Development" (March 1994), estimates the cost of upgrading of village roads and bridges in the "Desa Tertinggal" (IDT) villages2 at about US$40 million in Central Sulawesi and US$17 million in Southeast Sulawesi. 57. As part of the overall IDT program, OECF agreed to allocate about US$200 million equivalent for the upgrading over two years (1995/96 and 1996/97) of rural infrastructure in over 3,000 villages in 21 provinces, including the two Sulawesi provinces.3 Villages are being selected in clusters of five of which at least three should be [DT villages. An amount of US$65,000 equivalent is made available to each selected village for the construction of roads and bridges, water supply and sanitation systems, and jetties. Existing Government procedures l One could consider a Kecamatan committee per every 8 to 10 villages with each committee having a representative from one of the villages. 2 About 51 percent of the villages in the Central Sulawesi project areas, and 59 percent in Southeast, are listed as IDT villages. 3 A similar project, the Village Infrastructure Project (VIP) being financed by the Bank is under implementation in Java.
 80 ANNEX 1 will be followed for approval, financing and implementation of the program. A special INPRES4 will be allocated to the kabupaten and the works will be executed by contractors. Consultants/supervising engineers employed under the OECF financed project will assist the Dinas Public Works TK. II with the preparation of proposals and the design and supervision of the works. Project Intervention. 58. Like in the rest of the project provinces, the condition of access roads, tracks and trails to agricultural production areas in the targeted kecamatans is very poor. Access by motor vehicles and carts is constrained and frequently farmers must carry all inputs and output from the fields due to poor condition of the access roads. The project therefore provides for improving the physical access to the agricultural production areas where village irrigation, dryland farming systems development and estate crop demonstration activities have been implemented. Project assistance would be provided to support design and improvement of existing tracks, trails and rural roads that provide access to agricultural production areas. It is expected that a substantial part of the budget allocation will be used for the design and construction of bridges and culverts on existing rural roads and tracks which are critically in need of improvement. Farm access roads would be upgraded to compacted aggregate surface roads for use by motorcycles, animal drawn carts and four wheel vehicles. The alignments would be made on existing foot-paths, so there would be no need to acquire land. 59. In order to get the maximum participation of the population in the road construction program, the construction program will be implemented by the village resilience group, LKMD as is currently being done under the village infrastructure projects (VIP) being financed by the Bank and OECF. Design and technical support would be provided by the TK II Public Works Dinas in each Kabupaten. The construction manual, already prepared for the VIP project in Bahasa Indonesia, will be adapted during the first project year (by March 31, 1997) for use in implementing the component. A consultant rural engineer/contracts specialist will be recruited by the project to oversee the construction program and help with procurement and contracting. The consultant will be responsible for preparing the project specific manual based on the VIP model and on discussions with project beneficiaries. Expected Results 60. A total of about 660 kilometers of farm access roads would be upgraded to improve access to village irrigation schemes, dryland farm systems production areas and estate crops areas. Upgrading of farm to market roads would improve access to agricultural production areas so that farmers spend less time per trip to their fields and are able to increase the frequency of trips. Costs of transport of inputs and farm output would be effectively reduced. It is proposed that the maximum allocation for each participating kecamatan (25 each in 4A development program funded through a special authorization by Presidential Instruction.
 81 ANNEX 1 Southeast and Central) should not exceed Rp 450 million (US$200,000) though it could be less. K. Local Community Initiatives Background 61. The bottom-up planning system, as specified in Ministry of Home Affairs Regulation Number 9 of 1982, provides for the preparation of proposals for development activities from the village level with screening at the higher levels. The system has the potential to improve planning of project activities in order to respond more directly to the needs of the local people. The main constraints of this planning system are: (a) insufficient capacity at the village and kecamatan level to prepare proposals which are in line with the felt needs of the rural groups, and (b) insufficient discretionary funding at the kabupaten level to respond to these proposals. Lessons from Experience 62. The social assessment undertaken as part of project preparation reviewed the experience of different types of development programs financed in the two provinces. The general conclusion was that for projects to be sustainable, they require a high degree of community involvement and appropriation. Lessons indicate however that communities have seldom fully participated in the management of community-based development (CBD) programs. Social preparation to secure community commitment to and participation is very important and help has to be provided to most communities in developing initiatives due to weak village organizational structures. Similarly government officials need to be trained in community-based initiatives. 63. An approach that supported the development of community initiatives was tried under the NTASP financed by the Bank. The experience showed that significant benefits can be achieved from this approach. The ICR for NTASP5 observed that the overall development impact and sustainability of this component were quite good but would have been enhanced if program development had applied more rigorous criteria to define priority rankings for interventions. Project Intervention 64. The proposed project would support local community initiatives which are expected to result in direct benefits to the communities. Local leaders would be trained in community- based planning methods and support will be provided for farmer and community organization. The project would provide discretionary funding to support implementation of activities which are considered to be a high priority by the local community and are technically and economically feasible and environmentally sound. Though no specific limit has been set, it is expected that each kecamatan would receive about Rp 90 million during the project 5Implementation Completion Report for NTASP, June 1995.
 82 ANNEX 1 (equivalent to some Rp 22.5 million or US$10,000 annually for four years). Generally it is expected that a range of activities would be proposed in line with local conditions and community preferences. Priority would be given to proposals for activities to promote farming systems development which might include, but would not be limited to: revolving credit systems for, water buffaloes, goats and pigs; introduction of new agricultural technology; post- harvest processing and storage for food and estate crops; activities to control wild pigs; home industries; and community managed infrastructure development activities (mostly water supply and roads). 65. Proposals would be made annually through the village level planning process and with support from community development facilitators to be recruited under the project. The village level proposals, formulated by farmer groups and/or villages with assistance from the community development facilitators and/or CDOs, will be consolidated at the Kecamatan level and reviewed to prioritize those with the greatest socio-economic impact and those expected to improve rural incomes. The purpose of the review will be to ensure that proposed activities meet the necessary criteria and to rank the activities coming from the kecamatan by order of priority. The proposals will be forwarded to the Kabupaten, where the project steering committee would review the proposals to ensure that they conform to the agreed criteria for the component. 66. Guidelines for selection of activities for funding would be established so as not to delete the intent of eliciting priorities as identified by the community. A guide in Bahasa Indonesia would be prepared as part of the training program for Community Development Facilitators. To be selected for support by the project, the proposed schemes should meet the following criteria: o technically feasible and economically justified productive activities; * activities have to be identified by the population to be of high priority; - the population has to demonstrate that the activity is in their manifest interest by their willingness to contribute at least their labor, land and local materials where necessary to the realization of the activity; • the population has to demonstrate their willingness to provide for the operation and maintenance of activities financed under the sub-component. 67. In addition the following limits are expected to apply: (a) maximum amount per scheme: Rp 10,000,000; (b) maximum amount per beneficiary: Rp 250,000; (c) minimum number of beneficiaries per scheme will be 10 households except for sparsely populated areas where the minimum shall be 3 households.
 83 ANNEX 1 68. Preference would be given to proposals which: (a) benefit the poorest segment of the community (b) involve women and youth groups; (b) are assisted by local CDOs; (c) have the lowest risk of failure; (d) have the greatest socio-economic impact; and (e) have the highest proposed contribution by the community 69. Expected Results. The selected activities would measurably increase the incomes and levels of welfare among the low income groups in the target areas. It is expected that a minimum of 25,000 rural households would benefit from this activity.
