 93 ANNEX 2 INDONESIA SULAWESI AGRICULTURAL AREA DEVELOPMENT PROJECT Regional Assessment Institutes for Agricultural Technology (AIATs) Background 1. The main body for agricultural research in Indonesia is the Agency for Agricultural Research and Development (AARD) which was established by Presidential Degree in 1974. AARD is designated to coordinate, manage and conduct agricultural research and development all over Indonesia. To adapt to the changing demands of the agricultural sector, AARD's role has been evolving over time and is being assisted to meet this under the Bank assisted Second Agricultural Research Management Project (ARMP II). 2. The objective of ARMP II is to: (a) improve the efficiency and cost effectiveness of research and development(R&D) through decentralization of services to the regions, and (b) focus on specific agro-ecological zones (AEZ) and resource based development generating location-specific technologies. This would also help achieve a more balanced development between the regions. In addition, R&D activities would focus on market oriented and demand driven technologies to serve the changing needs of both farmers and consumers for higher quality and more diversified products. 3. Within the regional framework, the changing agricultural research strategy aims to generate location specific technologies using a farming systems approach (FSR). This will be achieved by five main related activities: * regional problem identification through better research-extension-farmer linkages; * closer collaboration between research and extension to generate and package technologies to meet local farmers' needs; * technology transfer which would link researchers, extension workers and farmers closer together; * organization of field days; and * production of materials and information which meet and recognize the absorptive capacity and educational level of the farmers. This departure from the strong sector and commodity based and centrally managed approach to research, demands a closer collaboration between regional research staff and local government staff (in particular extension), members of the private sector, (including CDOs), representatives of farmer groups as well as creating stronger links with regional universities, for specific research topics and training.
 94 ANNEX 2 4. AARD has taken action to reorient the mandates of 15 national commodity research institutes of which: five are involved in foodcrops; three in horticulture; three in industrial crops; two in livestock; and three in fisheries. Most of the stations of these national research institutes, together with the nearest agricultural support and service centers have been frilly integrated into 17 new Assessment Institutes for Agricultural Technology (AIAT) under AARD's Center for Agricultural Socio-Economic Research (CASER). Under ARMP II, the overall implementation of the AIAT programs is managed by one central Project Management Unit (PMU), headed by a central Director and assisted by a National Advisory Comnmittee. Each AIAT is headed by a regional Director and supported by a small Project Implementation Unit (PIU) under an ARMP II Sub-project Coordinator. The PIU Coordinator, supported by a few AIAT staff, reports directly to the AIAT Director, who in tum reports to the ARMP II Director. Only eight of the ALATs are Bank assisted under the ARM II Project, including the Kendari AIAT in Sulawesi Tenggara and the Biromaru AIAT in Sulawesi Tengah. The remaining 9 institutes will probably be financed directly by Government, ADB and other donors. The Sulawesi Regional Assessment Institutes for Agricultural Technology 5. The two Sulawesi AIATs are now being strengthened and staffed by AARD research staff, relocated from the national research stations to the regions, the two food crops sub- stations of Wawotobi in Sulawesi Tenggara and Sidondo in Sulawesi Tengah, and their respective Agricultural Information Centers (Balai Informasi Pertanian - BIP) in Kendari and Biromaru. In each province there is a Regional Advisory Committee (RAC) chaired by the head of each provincial BAPPEDA and co-chaired by the head of MOA's regional office (Kanwil), with members drawn from various Dinas-Dinas, local universities, farmers' groups, local CDOs and private sector. The RAC is expected to guide the AIAT and its Coordinator on the research & development program, priorities and policies. It will be assisted by a Regional Technical Working Group (RTWG) drawn from the various agencies. Since both AIATs also have to cover their neighboring provinces, Sulawesi Tenggara for Sulawesi Selatan and Sulawesi Tengah for Sulawesi Utara, both AIATs have two RACs and two RTWGs. Both AIATs have recently prepared their draft research work-plan proposals for the coming years, which have to be financed under ARNMP II, but still need to be approved by the central PMU at AARD. One of the first AIAT activities under the ARMP II project will be a FSR Baseline Survey to support area development farming systems and fisheries research and technology transfer. Support of the AIATs to the Proposed SAADP 6. In addition to their own programs under ARMP II, both AIATs will support the SAADP Project in certain areas of development in the two provinces. They will support the Project in the following three main areas. (a) assistance to the Dinas-Dinas Food, Estate Crops, Livestock and Fisheries extension agents in the transfer of proven agricultural technologies and in the design of the most relevant agro-technological demonstrations on farmers fields
 95 ANNEX 2 as funded under the Project. The Dinas-Dinas extension agents will remain responsible for the actual organization, lay-out and monitoring of the demonstrations and organize farmers groups discussion meetings; (b) carrying out specific applied, priority research projects in support of regional agricultural development and based on identified local specific needs; for this purpose the project provides 6 years of program funding; and (c) establishment, with the assistance of DGEC, of new superior mother trees stock gardens for cashew (Kendari) and cacao (Biromaru), 5 ha each, estimated at RP 61 million/ garden Specific funds will be made available for these three components under the SAADP Project to the two AIATs in Kendari and Biromaru to support the Project. A. Demonstrations of Crop Production Technologies 7. The recommended basic two year demonstrations to be carried out under the Project are: 8. Village inigated. rice and soybean production systems: based on local farmers capacity and needs. Project inputs will include: tested improved rice and soybean varieties, relevant fertilizer inputs, basic pest control chemicals and some equipment. The main technical themes will involve: proper land preparation, timely (trans)planting, proper crop husbandry and on- farm water management, reduction of harvest losses, etc. For rainfed sawahs, similar demos can be carried out, using more adaptable, less risky hydromorphic varieties and reduced inputs. 9. Dryland inter-cropped farming systems. Project inputs will include: tested improved maize and mungbean varieties (including improved cassava cuttings where appropriate), high quality cashew/other appropriate tree crop (including fruit tree) and leguminous tree seedlings, king grass (for cattle fodder) and vetiver grass (to reduce/control erosion), fertilizers and limited pesticides and some equipment. Demonstrations to be laid out on flat and steeper sloping lands. Common forms of dryland farming techniques are: alley cropping (tanaman lorong), contour ridge terracing (teras guludan), cover crops, living fences (pagar hidup) and bench terraces (teras bangku). 10. Rehabilitation of overgrown/closed in cashew farms. These demonstrations will mainly be carried out in Sulawesi Tenggara, in particular on the islands of Muna and Buton. Mature closed tree stands will be thinned out to some 33 trees/ha and interplanted with foodcrops and new improved cashew seedlings, which at a much later stage will replace the older cashew trees. Inputs: seeds, seedlings, fertilizers, some pesticides and equipment. Top grafting of young seedlings and coppiced unproductive trees with superior clonal material will also be demonstrated.
 96 ANNEX 2 11. Rehabilitation of cacao under coconut or other mixed trees. For cacao, it is recommended to apply proper pruning techniques to improve tree shape, fruit bearing and crop sanitation and to improve the quality of the shade trees, e.g. larntoro and gamal. Recommended densities for mature trees is 400 to 500 trees/ha. Inputs are: cacao seedlings and leguminous shade tree seedlings for replacement of old trees, fertilizers, some pesticides and equipment. 12. Improvement of House Plots and Home Gardens. On average village house plots/home gardens are about 0.2 ha and planted with a variety of crops (including vegetables) and fruit trees. Under the Project, these gardens will be improved to increase production and their nutritive and economic value. Better yielding fruit trees, vegetables and cash crops like vanilla, pepper and ginger will be made available from the village nurseries through the PKK in the village. The project will establish about 2 home garden improvement demos per village or 0.4 ha/village. One of the aspects of improved home gardening is to maximize the use of vegetative waste and cow manure into garden compost. Costs per home garden demonstration is estimated at RP 0.1 million, or RP 0.5 million/ha. B. Applied Priority FSR Program 13. The following applied research areas for the two AIATs, have been identified as relevant to the Sulawesi Tenggara and Tengah SAADP Project: (a) Farming Systems Research on Cattle Fattening, making better use of crop residues from dryland farms and leguminous trees clippings; (b) cashew research, including the introduction of vegetative multiplication, mainly by the Kendari AIAT; (c) cacao research, including setting up a biological control/IPM program, mainly by the Biromaru AIAT; (d) Fisheries and Coastal Ecosystems Research; 14. Although the SAADP draft Project Implementation Plan (PIP) provides a long list of research projects in the above four categories, none of the AIATs or local government staff met is familiar with the proposals. It is therefore recommended that during the first project year, these research project proposals be reviewed in light of the ARMP II, FSR Baseline Survey results (which should be completed by that time) and finalized by the two AIATs themselves at two regional research workshops to be organized with the Regional Technical Working Groups. Following the workshop's recommendations, and based on the actual available manpower and capability at the two Institutes and supporting agencies, a realistic research implementation plan for both AIATs will be developed. Such an approach will allow for a better distribution of research tasks among the two AIATs and prevent overlapping, thus reducing costs. To support the two regional FSR workshops, the SAADP Project would provide 2 man-months of technical assistance to help the AIAT's to establish their research
 97 ANNEX 2 priorities, in particular that of their FSR applied research program and to develop their research implementation plans. Both institutes would receive additional intemational assistance in developing their specific cashew and cacao research programs. C. The Establishment of Superior Cashew and Cacao Mother Tree Gardens. 15. Cashew. Sulawesi Tenggara is the main cashew producing province in Indonesia with some 125,000 ha. Cashew plantings are concentrated in the lower rainfall areas, especially on the islands of Muna and Buton. This crop has only been planted extensively by smalthoders during the last ten to fifteen years and spacing, inter-cropping, management, and processing practices are not always in accordance with technical recommendations. Initially, cashew plantings were recommended by the Government to improve erosion control on denuded and exhausted sloping and critical lands and to rehabilitate watersheds. Seeds and seedlings were collected from anywhere to follow the planting rush. As a consequence, cashew tree stands are very heterogeneous with all types of trees with different qualities and yield potentials. In some areas, smallholders have established monocrop cashew plantings on land traditionally used for foodcrops in response to the Government's promotion of cashew and have then cultivated marginal uplands instead. 16. The international market for cashew has been expanding continuously over the past 20 years. Therefore, as a most suitable industrial smallholders' crop, cashew has comparative advantages in supporting national policies for agricultural development, particularly in the Eastem part of Indonesia. Development of this crop could well contribute to increase farmers' incomes, export earnings and agro-industrial development. Unfortunately, because of the heterogeneity of the trees, productivity in Indonesia is relatively low in comparison with production levels in Brazil and neighboring countries, such as India, Thailand, Vietnam and Northern Australia. 17. Although Indonesia has a major research center for most commercial treecrops, there is no special research institute in Indonesia which deals particularly with cashew and the above described problems. Consequently, it is recommended that under the SAADP Project, AIAT Kendari gradually become a main cashew research activity center. To start this initiative, and with the assistance of the Dinas for Estate Crops, a 5 ha superior mother tree garden for cashew will be established in South Kendari under the SAADP Project, from where selected clonal materials will eventually be further disseminated to Dinas-Dinas and village nurseries. Because cashew can be easily vegetatively multiplied by top grafting or otherwise, the establishment of the clonal seed garden and the dissemination of vegetative material can be done relatively quickly. Besides financing a survey to identify potential high yielding and tolerant cashew mother trees in farmers' fields in Sulawesi Tenggara, the Project would finance (2 months) technical assistance for an international cashew specialist to assist AIAT Kendari and collaborating Dinas Estate Crops in setting up such a superior mother trees stock garden and provide guidance for developing its cashew research program. Total costs of the survey are estimated to be RP 10 million, mutually covered by the project budgets of the provincial Dinas Estate Crops and AIAT Kendari.
 98 ANNEX 2 18. Cacao. Cacao is one of the main commercial tree crops in Sulawesi, with the two project provinces Sulawesi Tenggara and Sulawesi Tengah in particular having a combined area of some 95,000 ha. The provinces are rapidly expanding their cacao production and are presently contributing more than 20% of the total national production. In particular Sulawesi Tengah has a great potential for expansion. In comparison with other cacao producing areas in Indonesia, Sulawesi is encountering its own production problems, due to poor quality of seed/plant stock materials, the spread of the Cacao Pod Borer (CPB) disease from the North, Helopeltis and the vascular streak dieback (VSD) disease. One of the recomnmendations by MOA is to eradicate affected trees and condomize the fruits. However no farmer is willing to cut down his cacao trees. Another problem are the heavy metals in many soils in Sulawesi, affecting the quality of the cacao beans and butter. Cultural practices (especially proper pruning and pest control) by local farmers are frequently less than adequate, since many farmers still consider cacao as a "forest" crop, that needs to be harvested only. Like in the case of cashew, research and extension support for cacao is inadequate and needs to be strengthened. 19. The main cacao research institute in Indonesia is in Jember, East Java. Considering however, the many new problems in production and expansion of cacao in Sulawesi, combined with the different agro-ecological environments, the experience and knowledge of the Jember cacao research institute may not be sufficient to answer the cacao production problems in Sulawesi. Therefore it is strongly recommended that with the assistance from Jember, AIAT Biromaru starts playing a much bigger role in cacao research for the Eastem Islands (including Halmahera in Maluku), in the areas of improvement of seed and clonal stocks and the development of biological control/IPM practices on farmers fields. Therefore, under the SAADP Project, a start will be made in establishing a realistic cacao research program for AIAT Biromaru and to establish a 5 ha superior mother tree garden in Sulawesi Tengah. The Project will provide international technical (2 man-months) assistance to AIAT Biromaru to develop the research program and to establish the mother trees garden (estimated costs: RP 61 million). Like in the case of cashew, Dinas Estate Crop will assist in the farmers' fields survey to identify potential tolerant and well producing mother trees. Total costs of the survey are estimated to be RP 10 million, mutually covered by the project budgets of the provincial Dinas Estate Crops and AIAT Biromaru. 20. doc.repnme: Indonesia - Sulawesi Agricultural Area Development Project
doc.abstracts: The overall objectives of the Sulawesi Agricultural Area Development Project are to assist the government in reducing the incidence of poverty in the provinces of Central and Southeast Sulawesi through the increase of rural incomes, the promotion of equitable regional development, the promotion of environmentally sustainable farming practices, and the strengthening of local level institutions. The specific objectives of the project are to: 1) increase farmer productivity and incomes; 2) promote environmentally sustainable farming practices; and 3) improve the capacity of local institutions to identify, prepare, appraise and manage agricultural development programs. The project has three broad components: 1) agriculture-based area development, including a crop development program, livestock management and veterinary care, farm access roads, and community based initiatives; 2) project management and capacity strengthening of local agricultural support services comprising the rehabilitation and improvement of facilities, training, workshops, seminars, and technical assistance; and 3) farming systems and fisheries research support and technology transfer.
